Having never tried this before surprised me when it was delivered to the table. Despite an odd pairing choice that it completely swamped I enjoyed this excellent imperial IPA. As long as it sticks to its roots I cant see it ever being completely edged out of the market - especially with what the Surly brand has become.

Aroma / Appearance - A golden bronze base packs the punch you would expect. Walloping the nose with nothing short of pure weapons grade hops it scours the sinuses clean with zero attempt at subtlety. If big massive IPAs are your thing this delivers in spades.

Flavor / Palate - Lemon custard, zest, and an urgent bitter sensation gnaw at the palate like gritty sandpaper. It manages to build even after you think theres no way for it to become more intense. The expertise to stop just short of total fatigue demonstrates a deft touch that is the only subtle thing about this world class imperial IPA.

16 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 11/2/2015. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy golden orange color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of huge grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, papaya, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, citrus rind, pine, light honey, bread, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome complexity and balance of dank citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate pale malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of huge grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, papaya, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, citrus rind, pine, light honey, bread, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Good amount of pine/citrus rind/herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, papaya, mango, lemon/orange peel, pine, light honey, bread, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dank citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate pale malt sweetness; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero astringent flavors after the finish. Good amount of dryness from bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, sticky/resinous, and lightly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an incredible DIPA. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dank citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate pale malt sweetness; and very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

text: Thick mouthfeel, golden yellow beer. Very hoppy, but a floral sweet hop. Very good.

Surly abrasive 15

Pours an orange-amber color, with a half finger broad, white head.

Intriguing aromas of grass, lime, pineapple and biscuity, sweeter malts. Due to the prominent malts, the fruity hops melt well into the beers sweetness, evoking aromas of juicy ananas dipped into honey, with a prikly kiwi peak to it. 

Lively, slightly metallic mouthfeel, highlighting the citrus qualities of the beer.

Tastes of citrus, with a dank quality to it and balancing, earthy malts. This is bursting with hops, unleashing a very bitter, slightly tropical onslaught, almost overpowering my palate. It does not, because of glazed malts, providing nothing more but a basic malt presence, letting the hops shine big times. Finishes with an immense, dry bitterness, accentuating citrus hops, which stay on the tongue for a very long time.

Pine and honey, accompanied by a subtle metallic hint, resulting from the carbonation, interact incredible well with the tongue numbing citrus bitterness, tranforming the taste more and more into a tropical fruit direction, due to the distinct, honeyed malts infusion. This beer is truly abrasive, while it highlights all the positive characteristics of a well composed IIPA. Its versatile in taste, while it provides a merciless bitterness, wrapped up by citraic fruits and honeyed malts.

Incredible pine and citrus aroma. Citrus sweetness just about perfectly balanced with heavy hop bitterness. Pours gold and drinks easy. Wouldnt guess 9% abv. Another great beer from Surly.

Tall boy can from 12-10-13...poured golden clear with 2 fingers of white head, mild carbonation and lacing. Nose is strong grapefruit and floral. Taste is layers of fruit and floral with a light mouthfeel and bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2017 First time I had this, it blew me away and was one of the first DIPAs I tried. Re-rating now... On tap at JL Beers in Grand Forks. Slightly hazy golden pour with a white head. Aroma is big and juicy, tropical fruit. Taste is similarly juicy and fruity, sweetness and balanced bitterness. Still a gorgeous beer.

A golden DIPA with a thin off white head. In aroma, beautiful floral hops, intense piney and citrusy character, over biscuit malt. In mouth, a nice citrusy biscuit malt with loads of pink grapefruit pulp, floral and resinous hops, very nice and complex, a good example of the style. On tap at End of Everything beer fest Dec 22 2013.

Canned 3/21/11

A: 16oz can wrapped in aluminum foil and topped with standard pull tab. So I pulled the tab and poured out some honey colored ale. Maybe a drop of vamp blood in there, but pretty washed-out. Transient fine white foam finds resolve as a thin, broken sheet of a surface - but collared. Quantity of lace is equivalent to a Paris Hilton personal film: none. (3.5)

S: Hops. IPA. Grapefruit among other citric rinds. Slightly sweet nose candy of a malt profile. Im guessing that theres quite a bite to this one. An unbaked bread smell - doughy. I keep thinking I can smell more and more...tangerine? Excited. (3.5)

T: The dough is the first thing I taste. Then flanking of bitter and spicy hops roll over my palate and the beer may even be over douching the beer with hops. Tannic. As the beer warms up the bitterness dies out a bit and the beer becomes relatively sweet. (4)

M: Medium body with low carbonation. Dry finish only slight heat (guessing ABV in the 7% range). I think maybe my teeth dislike this beer - the enamel is flecking off. (3.5)

O: Still guessing IPA and this one is sweet and definitely drinkable. Actually reminds me of Dales Pale Ale (also an IPA).

Serving type: can

05-28-2011

Can -- thanks, Jeff! Pours pale gold with white frothy head. Aroma: Big grapefruit and resinous nose. Taste: lightly sweet, big bitterness, lots of neat citrus hop flavor packed into this. Lasting bitter finish, as if youd expect anything else. Some sweetness is present, but only enough to carry the hops, which I like. Palate: full body, thick, creamy texture. Overall: This is the second can Ive had now, and Im digging it more than the first. Abrasive indeed, but in a way thats endearing once you get to know each other better.

Pours a nice golden hue with a medium head and lots of lacing. Aroma is citrus backed by some malt and a serious hop note. Taste is citrus with some robust hop notes and some malt and a hint of caramel in the middle. Palate is tantalized by lots of different hop characteristics. Backed up by some nice malt and a crisp finish. Great drinkable beer that masks the ABV well.

Thanks to Whit for this. Pours a foggy golden yellow with a smallish white head and good lacing. Aroma is intense citrus hops. Probably the most intense citrus hopped beer Ive had. Taste is surprisingly well balanced for the nose. Big citrus hops are there and a nice bitterness tingles the palate but its well balanced with sweet resin from the hops and grains.

Can courtesy of bnielsen13. Thanks Brad! Pours a golden color with white head. Fresh citrus, grapefruit, orange, hoppy aromas. Strong, hoppy, citrus, grapefruit, bitter, slight boozy flavors. Really nice double ipa
Huge pineapple hop aroma. Tons of fresh hop taste and the sweet hops sticks with you through the taste. Very good.

Refrigerated 16 oz. aluminum can from BVery (canned on November 27, 2013) poured into a snifter. Pours hazy light orange with medium white head. Aroma is evergreen hops, medium body, lower carbonation, and thin big bubble lacing. Taste is evergreen hops, balancing malt, and bitter finish. Pretty good DIPA with a nice richness.

Can. Pours slightly hazy amber with a medium sized, lacing off-white head. Aroma og citrus, peach and caramel. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and nice bitter. Medium bodied, oily text. and soft carb. A great brew indeed.

slightly hazy pale yellow with white head. Very strong aroma of pine and citrus. strong pine grapefruit taste with bitter bite at the finish. Very heavy malt feel. Unbalanced IPA, but very good. For those who like a slap in the face with hops.

16 ounce can. Thanks Jeff! Pours a slightly hazy light gold with a large white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, and grass. Taste is grapefruit, other tropical fruits, pine, grass, florals, and some malt. Massive amounts of hops.

Can into a tulip. Pours golden with white head that dissipates quickly. Nice floral, citrus nose. A little bit of sweet malt coming through too. Taste is pine-sol and sweet malt. Harsh finish. Definitely is abrasive. Pretty darn good.
Can. Shocked by the strength of the sweet malt backbone. Good combo of pine, citrus and resinous hops in aroma and taste. Excellent DIPA.
Light floral aroma. Rich, cloudy golden color. Well balanced citrusy hops. Smooth palate. Worth trying. One of the better double IPAs that you will find.
Draft: golden amber with a thin white head, citrus, hoppy aroma, taste is dry, very dry. An excellent DIPA.

Had this many times but for some reason never rated it. This is one of my favorite Surly brews. Clear amber pour with a nice white head. Pine and citrus nose. Big hop taste and bitterness fades into a nice malty citrus sweetness. Excellent.
awesome ass beer. most fragrant and beautifully aroma i have ever smelled. very pleasant on the palate, very nice bitter and citrusry hop aroma, beautifully taste. awesome awesome awesome
Tap. Light copper color . Sweet pine and alcohol. Typical double ipa taste elements . Finishes very dry. A bit of grapefruit. I liked it.

Tap pour at Pizza Luce Hopkins. Abrasive is an extremely apt description. Hits you both on the nose and in the mouth with hops. Strong citrus flavors with emphasis on grapefruit. Tastes very refreshing. Hides the alcohol well and finishes on a high note. MN beers know hops and this one lives up to that reputation.

Can you say hops?

Great earthy taste. Very bitter, mouthfeel is very smooth, but perfectly carbonated.

Clear Orange with a thin foamy head and mild carbonation; Good lacing. Nose and aroma of mangos, apricots, grapefruits, tangerines, citrus & piney hops and caramel malts. Malty/resin aftertaste. Heavy body and mild-moderate carbonation. Outstanding Imperial IPA!

A: Hazy Orangish/Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

S: Grapefruit Rind, Oranges, Piney

T: Piney, Grapefruit Rind, Mild Bittering Hops

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Bitter, Mildly Drying

Overall, i liked this beer better than Furious, similar qualities without the maltiness.

Pours a cloudy peach color with a fairly large frothy white head. Aroma is loads of fresh tropical fruit - mango, grapefruit, peach, lychee - along with newly mown grass, honey and resin. Taste is equally tropical with grapefruit, mango, peach, apricot. Also some grass, resin, caramel and honey. Aftertaste finds grapefruit, honey, resin and hop bitterness. So very good!!

Can. Light amber body, nice white head. Aroma is grassy with dry malt, apricot, peach, flowers, quite intense on the gras sside. Taste is hoppy with pine and grass, layers of tropical fruit, bread. High lasting bitterness, massive hop complexity.
Pours amber with a white head. Smells resiny with some citrussy elements. Tastes resiny with lots of bitter citrus and a grassy finish.

16oz can to oversized tulip. Fresh and magnificent! Welcome to the hop show! Each and every description is abundantly present, resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs! Every IBU is displayed in radiant glory! This Imperial is pale gold with light haze and minimal head. I would describe the malt if I could find it. There are layers upon layers of steeped hop dank juicy boozy bitterness! Intent on its mission to sandblast your nostrils , Abrasive succeeds in shredding your Palate!
Can at home. Pours orange with an off white head. Aroma is lots of pine and citrus and some malt. Flavor is pine, citrus, resin and a little malt. Very nice beer, one of my favorites.

17-OCT-2013, can @home, from Mikkeller & Friends.
Hazy orange with creamy off-white head.
Very bitter hoppy aroma with grape fruit, pine, grass, and exotic fruits.
Taste the same. also malty with caramel and toast. Not as sweet and malty as some but crispyer.
Oily body, medium carbonation, long long bitter finish. Extremely bitter. Really fine IIPA. I could use some more malt but I can live with the crispness as well. Fine.
aroma is pine spruce light fruity. yellow beer with nice white head. taste is light sweetness and then heavy bitterness. light body soft carbonation. long very bitter dry finish.

0,5l can from mikkeller and friends, copenhagen. Little hazy golden color, big white head. Aroma is malty body, hops, fruits, some citrus. Nice sour fruit taste, citrus notes, malty body on the back, different hops. Quite nice.

16oz can brought back from Minn by the boys. Grandma would call them the "big boys". Thanks! Pours a hazy pale orange with a white slightly foamy head. Nice lacing. Aroma is lovely. Fruits, pine, citrus and some caramel. Further down the glass some herbal oniony spices. Florally strong and sweet! Taste is of sweet pitted fruits (mango, melon), spicy pine, bitter grapefruit and a solid core of sweet caramel malts. Very strong and bittersweet. Medium bodied and sticky. Finishes more bitter than sweet, and progressively more bitter. A bit more one dimensionally citrus/herbally hoppy than Furious smoothly oily hoppiness, but a really good, tasty brew.
Doften är sura plommon, gräs och aningen fotsvett. Smaken är tropisk mango, söt och maltig. Väldigt god avslutning med smak av grapefrukt. Mycket trevlig IIPA!
CBC 2013. Pours pale amber with a small off white head. Aroma is hoppy floral fruity malty. Flavor is piny citric grapefruits bitter malty.
Till skillnad från de mesta US-ipor vi ser i Sverige så är humlen lite piggare och malten håller sig lite mer i bakgrunden. Härligt. Inte så tung som väntat. Grapefruktdrag

On tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013. This is a near clear lovely looking golden one with a medium sized heavy lacing just off-white top thats really sticking to the side of the glass. On the nose I get fruity resinous hops, lots of grapefruit, some nectar and even traces of kiwi. Nice and powerful. Really resinous and strong hoppy on the flavor. A comfortable and delicious carbonation level inside a mild oily mouthfeel. Again, grapefruit is present here, it feels really concentrated this. Loads of fresh hops! In the finish I get some clear notes of cognac. Has this been barreled on something? Anyhow, a really nice acquaintance! 03.05.2013

Sample at CBC 2013.

hazy golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour of citrus, hops, malt, grapefruit and grassy notes.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2013 Can from Mikkeller & Friends. Pours golden brown with a short khaki head. Nose is tropical punch bowl with big caramel malt and resin hops. Almost like an imperial hipster ale. Taste is big malty sweetness, caramel and honey combined with grapefruit, pineapple and lychee. Smooth body with a big but contained bitterness. One of the best beers Ive had.

Can. Clear golden yellow with a medium sized off white good lacing head. Peach, melon, mango, lychee, lime, grain, caramel, a little warming alcohol in the finish. Taste is medium sweet and bitter. Full body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Medium bitter finish with tropical fruits.

Can. Pours slightly hazy light golden with stable white head. Clear aroma of hops with notes of citrus and grass. Bitter, hoppy flavour with pronounced citrus notes and touches of fruit and grass. Dry aftertaste. Not aggressive or abrasive. Just nice.
Can. Teaish hop aroma. Cloudy dark yellow colour. Big stable plasticky white head. The flavour is sweet and bitter. Has a good piney and resiny hop flavour.
3rd May 2013CBC. Bit of tired end of session rating. Light haze on this gold beer. Little white head. Light palate, crisp and dry. Big marmalade hops, fresh and rich. Minerally crisp finish. Nice!

Dåse: Lysegul diset øl med et flot skumhoved. Super lækker duft af græs og en lille snert citrus. Mundfylden er fabelagtig med en solid maltsødme til at bakke alkoholen og den yderst velkomponeret humlesmag sammen. Lækker lækker øl.
Can at Mikkeller & Friends. Hazy golden, huge head. Amazing citrussy hops aroma, rich and uncompromising. Fruity, hints of oranges, pineapples, even bread. Well-crafted, refreshing, complex.

Can from Mikkeller & Friends (after remortgaging). Pours hazy gold with thin, patchy white head and light lacing. Aroma is BIG: loads of mango, grapefruit, citrus, pineapple, pine resin, some light herbs. Taste is equally massive, with pithy grapefruit, blood orange, sweet tangerine and mango combining with oily pine resin and light grassiness. Only a touch of biscuity malt - the hops have free reign here. Incredible bitterness - pine and pithy grapefruit assault the palate. Full and oily mouthfeel. Pine and grapefruit linger long into the aftertaste. No hint of the booze - very drinkable. Incredibly impressed by this beast, well worth the price - a real rarity in Europe. Glad I've got a couple more cans!
Thanks to StFun for including this in a trade. Well balanced beer, with a subtle note of mango and tropical fruit in the top profile. Excellent.

Can, bought @ Mikkeller Bar, Viktoriagade. Pours clear golden with a large, staying, creamy, white head. Aroma has lovely peach, grapefruit, luscious oranges. Medium carbonation, very dry and quite creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has mild maltiness, heavy bitter hops. Grapefruit, oranges, peach, light pine. Lingering heavy fresh fruity bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 (sample courtesy of Mark, big thanks!) Pours a clear golden with little, white head. Aroma is piney spicy hops. Oily texture, medium to full body, medium carbonation and a bitter, somewhat warming finish. Flavour is well balanced with moderate bitterness and some sweetness.

Frisk lukt med preg av lys malt, masse humle, kattepiss, sitrus, lauv, sevje, sukker, gras. Frisk lett tørr smak med preg av lys malt, humle, lauv, høy, barnåler, bark, gras, sitrusskal, litt kattepiss. God bitterhet som set litt. God.
16 oz can to snifter (thanks jmborggren). Looks good; a hazy orange with sticky white lacing. Smells good too; a nicely balanced hop profile with a good semi-sweet backbone. Damn good!

Tap at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013 - Session 1. Pours clear yellow with a fine, white foam head. Lots of fresh grapefruit in here, some melon and tangerine. Medium to full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Good and resinous on the finish with lots more juicy, sticky citrus fruits. A really nice DIPA.

bottle share at BW - pre-hill farmstead 3rd anniversary. can. cloudy pale yellow with a nice white head, some retention. fresh grainy and lemony, citrus, light pine, hint of caramel. average carbonation, light body - oily, hint of sweetness, but overall nice balance. ends with a relatively short but nice citrusy-lightly piney finish. nice!

Can (500 ml). 4 month old. Thank Levi! Hazy golden with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma of caramel, hops, resinous notes and citrus. Taste is moderately sweet with caramel, hops, citrus, resinous notes and moderate bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium body. Moderately dry. Good DIPA, not too sweet. I would love to try is fresher.

Pours a liht orange with white head and nice lacing. Aroma of grapefruits, caramel, piney. Taste is grapefruits, orange peel, piney, caramel, light sweetness. Medium body and medium carbonation. This one was a bit old but still enjoyable. Will revisit.

Draught @ CBC 2013. Pours hazy golden with a good lacing and mostly lasting frothy white medium head. Aroma is citra, grass, grapefruit, tropical fruit and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily/creamy, carbonation is moderate. Finishes dry and bitter with citrus. Nice.

On tap @CBC13. Clear golden with small offwhite head. Aroma is malt, caramel, lots of hops with citrusy and piny notes. Taste is intense; caramel and loads of hop flavor. A bit too bitter for my liking, but a good dipa.

Pint can in a tulip.  Pours cloudy golden with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of a lot of citrusy and resinous hops plus a nice pale/caramel maltiness to balance it.  Flavor of a lot of citrus with a good amount of balance.  Smooth texture.  A really good double IPA.

Ill only rate a few bees at 100% and this is one of them.  If you like grapefruit juice and can get it buy a 4 pack.  One of the best tasting and smelling beers Ive ever had.  This one sets the bar.  You cant taste the ABV but you sure can feel it.  2 of these and youll probably be buzzing pretty good.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a pretty thick off-white head that settles after a bit and laces. What a nose: thick dank hoppy goodness with a smattering of stone fruit, grapefruit, yeasty dough, and biscuits and honey malt. Quite sweet but very bitter, really nicely balanced actually, which makes it incredibly drinkable. Full bodied yet not really heavy, toward syrupy but stopping just short, creamy and oily, with an exquisite drying bitterness to end it. Damn good brew, does everything you want a DIPA to do. Seriously awesome. You Minnesotans are some lucky bastards, minus the whole losing your real hockey team 20 years ago (which is still bullshit).

Keg @ CBC 2013. The pours deep gold with a small head. The aromas unwashed peaches, skunky hop bitterness. General sweet caramel candy, grass shoots. THe taste is quite aggressively bitter. Strong grassy hops. Light orchard fruit sweetness to balance. More apricot and peach. Full body, moderate carbonation. Overall, quite good.

Draught @ CBC. Pours deep golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, biscuit, rich hops, grapefruit, pine. Flavor is malt, caramel, biscuit, rich bitter hops, grapefruit, pine, resin. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, lasting bitter finish. 030513
Sample @ CBC. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, flowers, mango, grapefruits, pine, hops and malt.

Draught @ CBC2013. Pours tiny hazy yellow with a frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is fruity with crackers, dried apricots, passionfruit, mango, lemon grass, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, freshly cut grass, pine needles and hints of resinous wood and alcohol. Taste is bitter and fruity with crackers, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, lychee, cape gooseberries, apricots, passionfruit, lemon grass, mango, starfruit, freshly cut grass, pine needles and resinous wood. Mouthfeel is slightly crisp, dry, slightly astringent and medium bodied. Finish is bitter and fruity with grapefruit juice, pineapple, lychee, apricots, mango, grapefruit rinds and lots of pine needles, freshly cut grass and resinous wood. Very tasty...

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2013 Can. Pours a clear golden color with a small offwhite head. Aroma is very assertive hops, sweet caramel malts, and orange/grapefruit pith. Intense hop flavor; earthy, floral, grapefruit, pine, resin-like. Full bodied and a bit ABRASIVE. Some serious lingering bitterness happening here.

text: On tap at CBC. Clear golden-orange colour, with white head.  Hoppy aroma with some caramel. Hoppy taste, with sweetness and bitter ending. Medium body.
Tap @ CBC. Clear deep golden with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops, citrus and grapefruit. Flavour is malt, fruit, hops, citrus, grapefruit, bitter, pine and a little sweet.
CBC. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and rather hoppy - fruit and grapefruit. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 030513

[5/3/13] Draught at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013. Pretty clear deep golden. Great hoppy aroma with citrus, pine, some tropical fruits and some "green" character. Bitter flavor with light sweetish touch and nice piney and fruity hops. Medium-bodied. Very good.
Draught. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Long heavy bitter fnish. Creamy palate.
Tap @ CBC2013. Clear golden color, short head. Aroma of pine and grapefruit, caramel malt. Very bitter taste. Quite straightforward DIPA. Clean and crisp.
Fantastic double IPA, grapefruits and exotic fruits in the aroma. Very tropical with a long bitter finish. Very full bodied and bold and extremely tasty

Draught @ CBC 2013: Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Aroma: Herbs, flowers, citrus, tropical fruits. Flavour. Full of tropical notes, flowers, grape, herbs, some caramel. Medium to full bodied. Ends heravily floral bitter. Nice.
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2013 Sampled @ CBC 2013. Clear yellow to golden color, small white head. Smell and taste malts, tropical fruits, mandarin, mango, grapefruit, bitter and hops. What a beer, superb!
Tap @ CBC. Yellow orange slight hazy. Intense american citrus flavors. Medium body with robust bitterness. Long finish.You can drink gallons of this brew.

Draught at CBC 13. Clear golden liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, mango, biscuit, grass and weed. Awesome aroma. Taste is dry and medium to high bitter with notes of pine, citrus, mango and light grain. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Delicious.

Tap at CBC 2013.  Pours clear golden with an off white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, grass, tropical fruits and orange.  Flavor is light to moderate sweet and heavy bitter.  Medium bodied with light carbonation.

Pours orange with low white head. Aroma is pine, citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit. Taste is resiny bitter with a light fruit sweetness to balance it. Body is light and oily with soft carbonation.

Draught @ CBC2013. Pours a golden hazy colour with a white head. Aroma of heavy floral hops, grass and caramel. Flavour of heavy caramel malts, floral hops, grapefruit and some alcohol. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel and a heavy, floral, piney finish. Really heavy and good.

Draught @ CBC 2013

Pours clear golden yellowish with a smooth head. Aroma of super fresh hops, lemon, citrus, exotic fruits and malts. Taste is fruity, hoppy and lemony with some citrus, exotic fruits and zesty notes. Finish is warming and fruity with some zesty lemon and herbal touch. Nice, hoppy and fruity DIPA, but the alcohol comes through a bit too much.

Draught at CBC 2013. Clear golden beer with a small offwhite head. Fruity hop aroma, citrus, caramel, grass, earthy, grapefruit notes. Hoppy floral flavor, earthy, grapes, pine needles, mango, woody, long intensive bitterness, hay, herbal notes. Full bodied and with a very nice long bitter herbal fruity finish. Really good.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2013 Poured from a can into a tulip glass. Pours a nice semi-clear golden/amber color. Aroma is very hoppy of orange, fruit, citrus, and grapefruit. Flavor is very orange/fruity hop heavy initially while the finish is very astringent bitter hops of average duration. Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is average. Overall this is an alright beer not sure if i would have again.

Can from a generous trader. Pours orange gold with off white head. Nose and taste of fresh pineapple, grapefruit, resin, pinewood, citrus and orange peel. Medium body. Bitter grapefruit hash/resin finish.
Can at RBJG#2 - Grand Tasting Tims Place. Clear yellow - white head. High hoppy, sweetness, dry bitterness, grape fruits, lemon, grassy, lovely, light sweet malty.

Pours a lighter color than Furious, more in line with what I would expect from a DIPA. Nice clear amber color with a healthy white head. Smell is very tropical and floral with citrusy undertones. Taste again follows, but the malt is clearly evident. Solid DIPA.
Can. Tastes like the unholy love child between a McDonalds McChicken sandwich and a day-old piece of Pizza Hut pepperoni pizza. Tastes like it was dry-hopped with oregano.

Pours a medium cloudy amber color with a grapefruit aroma and a small off white head.  Grapefruit is definitely well balanced with the malts for a smooth, slightly bitter finish.  This is a great DIPA!

16oz can. Pours a hazy amber orange color with 1 finger of slightly off white head. Aroma is loads of tropical fruits and grapefruit. Taste is tons of bitter grapefruit, pineapple, tangerine, peach, mango. Just an abundance of fruit flavors as well as some pine and resin bitterness, and a tiny bit of caramel malt.

16 oz can shared by jsprime. Clear light orange with a white head. Huge hoppy nose. The flavour is also extremely hop forward. There is a big bitter finish and this is also quite dry for an IIPA. Really well made hop bomb.

16 oz. can pours a clear orange color with one-finger white head and good lacing.  Smell is strong, with citrus, melons, and -dare I say it - cat piss.  This one is a hop bomb which assaults the taste buds in a great way for those of us who love over-the-top IIPAs.  Aroma has lots of apricot, grapefruit, honeydew melon, passion fruit, dank and a slight bit of caramel malt.  Taste is bitter most of the way through with a long bitter finish but without anything foul.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Body is medium with lively carbonation.  Mouthfeel is slightly sticky.   My rating would be higher if this had more malts to balance the hops or if it werent so expensive.  Still, this was the highlight of my recent trip to Minnesota.

I could have swore I smelled apricots, but its always a crapshoot trying to detect the faintest hint of each ingredient. Nevertheless, it sometimes tastes like a moist, pungent cooter, which is awesome.

Can to New Belgium globe. Apricot honey colored pour with a rocky two finger white head. Fairly well laced. Dank aroma with juniper and tangerine pith. Taste is resinous with a touch of cereal and a slightly sweet grapefruit finish.  Otter grapefruit lingers on the palate.  Above average drying of the mouth.  Full flavored and well crafted.
Hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is bread, cheese, flowers, passionfruit. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, bittersweet on the palate. Taste is grapefruit, honey, passionfruit, caramel.
clear golden pour with some lace. Piney-grapfruit zest aromas. lots of grapefruit pith in flavour. slightly oily mouthfeel. finishes with a semi dry tangerine sweet finish
Can at Tims RPJG#2. Sweet and dry. Lots of hops aromas. Spruce and residual sugars. Medium to full bodied. Soft carbonation. Dry finish.

Pours somewhat clear of yeast, sunset golden, burnt amber like with 1 finger frothy head which over time simmers down. Aroma very apparent, and backed up with bold flavor. At first very smooth almost creamy, then transitions into powerful blast of flavor to your whole mouth missing no taste buds whatsoever.
Holy smokes, what a IIPA. And from a can, too! Great floral/resin/herbal aromas, super fizzy, loads of flavor. Dont miss this one.
Can at RBJG 2 Grand Tasting, thanks TokyoCraft. Hazy golden colour with almost no head. Citric hop aroma. Flavour of hops, flower, perfume.
Orange, thin white head. Nose is flowers, herbs, vegetable, egg roll. Taste is tropical fruits, egg roll, deli sandwich, hoppy finish. Very juicy mouthfeel.
Canned. Typical huge fruit salad nose, peaches, melon, mango. Nice glowing colors. Flavors of cat piss, nice malts, fruitscitrus and tropical. Good balance. Dig it.

Pours a crystal clear pure golden color with an antique white head. The head is quite stubborn, contributing to the aesthetics of the beer. It has primarily a grapefruit nose with some pine breaking through. The bouquet is vibrant and it doesnt fade as the head dissipates. It has a big, thick, full mouthfeel with the perfect amount of carbonation to accentuate the entire experience. The usual pine and grapefruit flavors, but with an extraordinary balance. Ive begun to notice that with these IPAs, the key component is balance. Nose, mouthfeel, flavor, finish--this one has it. It all works well together like a well-oiled machine.
Big caramel backbone, hugely caramel notes with pine and citrusy notes. Big over the top tomorrow and everything is good with this beer. So balanced.

On draft at ChurchKey DC during the Craft Brewers Conference.  Pours a hazy amber with an off white head.  Very aromatic fruity citrus nose.  Flavors of  orange giving way to grapefruit zest   Bitter finish.
citrus, golden, cloudy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, thick feel, long finish, bitter,
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2014 Can. Pleasant grapefruit citrus aroma. Smooth taste and palate easy to drink. Easily enjoyable.
Bottle at a bottle share. Pours a clear light golden color. Nose is bitter and hoppy, just like the taste. Nice fresh IPA. Great beer.

got this in a trade form bacterial.  Great aroma, more on the resiny and piney side for the hops, with a little pineapple coming through. I like IPAs with appropriate names and Surly Abrasive is a great example of why. Not quite a textbook example of either a West Coast or East Coast double IPA, but a big beer thats relentless in its bitterness, but still manages to be easy drinking and satisfying. 

I poured a 16oz can into a goblet.

Appearance: Hazy, translucent gold. Forms a large, ivory, frothy head which retains and laces excellently. 

Smell: Light, clean, tropical fruit notes at first, but upon closer inspection theres a strong earthy/herbal scent of resin and pine.

Taste: If you want hops you definitely get them with Surly Abrasive. Theyre here from the moment it hits your tongue until long after the swig is completed. Though the aroma is clean and fruity, the actual flavor is dank and resinous. Intense bitterness envelopes the palate with an almost pine-sap like flavor and character. Theres definitely orange citrus in the palate here as well, but its closer to juice concentrate or syrup than any kind of light, crisp, refreshing taste. Whats interesting is that its never really all that sweet and certainly not cloying. I get some subtle garlic or dry spice flavors on the backend, almost a bit of "locker room" funky taste as well which imparts a hint of candy tartness. 

Its a delicious tasting beer for sure, but not quite something Id award my highest grade to because its so unrelenting in its delivery and the flavors that are here, though great, could probably be even better. If I could get this on a regular basis I would, though. 

Drinkability: While Surly Abrasive may be one of the overtly bitter beers Ive ever had, what really makes it memorable is its easy drinkability. The mouthfeel is fairly soft, but lively, with a smooth texture and accompanying finish. Theres no challenge to get this beer down at all despite the fact its pretty hefty at 9% ABV. Still, the alcohol is well masked as I dont smell or taste it at all. The hops do make it rather astringent, so there is noticeable drying of the tongue. This would be a fantastic beer to pair with a spicy meal, though.

The taste is equally acidic, juicy fruit and bitter with a dank and garlic background. The malts are very much a background player here. Finished with a slight teabaggy dryness and some alcohol. The mouth feel is highly aggressive to the point of almost becoming annoying. Yep. A very nice DIPA but could be a touch more balanced but the name could not remain Abrasive.
Can from Bierkoning. Wow. Light amber with top head. Nice hoppy nose. Taste is nice and punchy. Lots of hops packed in there. Nice and bitter finish. Enjoyable.

Can 1pt.16fl.oz.Unclear medium to dark orange colour with a small average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, orange - citrus, riped orange, acrid bitter, grapefruit. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120320]

Originally reviewed: 7/12/10. Poured into a tulip glass. Pours a dark amber hue with a thick off-white head on top. Excellent retention; left spotty lacing all over the glass. Big, powerful citrus notes waft out. Lots of pineapple, grapefruit, with a touch of pine needles. 

The body on this beer is a disappointment though. Very slick and thin. Expecting a full-bodied beer, the flatness really let me down. Great flavoring of grapefruit, some sweet orange, candied malts (gives it a sweet punch), and a great bitter afterbite. This is a good beer. Tweak that mouth and this is a stellar beer.

(Can) Pours light hazy dark orange to amber with a creamy off-white head. The aroma holds peach, canned pineapple, pear, apple juice, wild strawberries, mango/passion fruit sorbet, juicy melon, lychee, perfume, dank herbs, weed, grass, spicy pine, black tea, mild grapefruit, orange, cheese, toast, caramel and a touch of bread. The nose is fairly complex but not super aggressive (more on the subtle side if you as me). The flavor is light sweet, medium bitter and tiny acidic with notes of citrus, wood, pine, herbs, grass, light fruits and clean toast. The mouthfeel is round, creamy and soft with a light carbonation. Pine and grapefruit on the finish. Lingering yet balanced afterbitterness. Medium bodied.
Awesome beer!  Probably my favorite Imperial IPA.  I wish they made this year round, but I suppose their Furious will have to do until next year!  Cant wait to try their Wet.
Can, golden pour. Big resiny hop filled aroma. Big hop flavor, tea notes, great flavor, not harsh bitterness. Easy drinking 9% DIPA. Need more surly

Tasting from a can on 1/14/12. Canned 12/14/11, poured into a Dogfish Head signature glass.

A: Appearance is cloudy copper with a tanish head. Light levels of lacing throughout the tasting.

S: Where do i start? Smells like pine, grapefruit, big on hop aroma. Overall, smells intense like a big DIPA should. Reminds me of Maharaja.

T: Grapefruit, pine, citra (?) hops, and tangerine. Get a little bit of the alcohol on the finish but just enough to know its there.

MF: Medium mouthfeel with lower levels of carbonation (maybe felt that way due to the high ABV?) and a drier finish. Smooth.

O: This is one of my favorite Surly brews and DIPAs in general, im very fortunate to be able to find this locally. I cant help but compare it to Avery Maharaja which i think is fairly similar in style and complexity. I remember taking down a couple of growlers of this stuff with friends when it was called 16 Grit. Have loved it ever since. Im glad i only have 11 more in my cellar to finish up. =)

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 01-14-2012 21:32:05

Draft at Churchkey for the Surly event. GIGANTIC scallion, onion, leek, hot mulch, and cheesecloth on the nose. So fresh and SO dank. The same holds true for the flavor; very little sweetness of any sort, just huge onion and evergreen. Still, awesome.

Wonderful light amber/copper pour with thick white head.  Aromas of grapefruit and spruce.  Nice malt flavor, touch of sweetness from the honey.  Medium bodied , great dry finish, bitterness throughout.  Overall, an outstanding IPA with the balance between  hops and malts.

Can @ Yespr. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Fruity malty hoppy bitter grapefruit aroma. Fruity malty hoppy bitter grapefruit flavor piney hints. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter piney finish.

Pours hazy orange with white head. Pine needles on the nose sweetness too. Big flavors of the forest. Grass, alfalfa, honey, pine needles..sweetness and bitterness working together seamlessly. Wish I had a never ending supply.
Amber colour. Interesting aroma here, alfalfa, moss, grass, pine. Taste is bitter pine. A great IPA.

Pours orange amber with a small white head.  Theres a lot of pine in the nose with some resin.  The taste is hoppy with heavy bitterness, a light sweet malt backbone, and a long dry bitter finish. This one will definitely scorch the palate, but its pretty good.
Like furious, but better.  Although I still dont think its as good as everyone makes it out to be.

Can at yespr.
Cloudy orange coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, pine needles and petroleum with notes of grapefruits.
Fruity flavour of hops and pine needles with notes of grapefruits.
Dry hoppy finish.

Thanks to Baron for the can!  Poured into a Heady Topper pint glass.  Wow, you can smell the hops the second you crack the can.  Lots of dank, grassy, pine-cone laden hops permeate the air around the glass.  Sweet caramel malts and a touch of honey on the nose as well.  Body is a vibrant cloudy orange with about a fingers worth of white, creamy, head.  Leaves some nice lacing behind.  Juicy grapefruit and bready malts on the tongue.  Nice lingering hop bitterness.  Piney with caramel.  Delicious.  Low, but adequate carbonation with some nice weight to the body.  An excellent DIPA all around.  Even better than remember it being the first time I had it.  Highly recommended.

Can. Light unclear golden with a decent white head. Gee, this Is a hoppy one: Peach, ripe pineapple, citrus, some herbal hops too. Flavor is big and bold, - sweet malty and toasted, fruity hoppy, a little resin on the tongue. Long lingering bitter finish.

1 pint can. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is peachy, mango and passion fruity. Smooth fruity, crisp hoppy and mango. Smooth, bitter and light citrusy. Light bitter and hoppy finish.

Can at Papsoe. Pours hazy deep golden with a medium off white head. The aroma has loads of exotic fruity notes. Its like walking into a candy store. Sweet peaches, passion fruit, mango, pineapple, citrus and it has a good caramel backbone. The flavour is highly fruity and has loads of caramel in it. It has notes of passion fruit, peaches and mango. Very nice.

cloudy golden, small white head.
nice hoppy aroma, pine, grapefruit, fruit peel, faint oranges. malts quite weak. flavor is strong hoppy, pine, grapefruit,

Can. A hazy amber beer with  beige head. The aroma has notes of hops, alfa acid, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of hops, lemons, alcohol, and malt, leading to a dry, bitter, and alcoholic finish.

Can 1 pt. Courtesy of Skyview. Pours amber with a slight haze and a lacing off-white head. Lovely hoppy aroma, citrusy but mainly peachy. Medium body, heavily fruity, a solid and sophisticated hop bill and a dry and bitter finish. For a style often out of balance, this is perfectly balanced. 200312

Pours a really nice caramel color with a hint of peach hues. 1 inch head that fizzled away.

Smells a bit nutty with some citrus and pine. Doesnt smell like it is going to be very bitter. A little funky.

Each sip hits the tongue with a sharp bite but then quickly smooths out with some sweetness. Definitely not as hoppy as a west coast IPA. I enjoy these more balanced hoppy/malty beers and think they have a high drinkability.

Leaves my palate candy-coated and I cant wait to get the chance to try this again.

NIce looking beer, wonderful golden color with a big frothy head. I love surly but this beer just doesnt do it for me like the others. smells like a tropical wonderland but taste like a one dimensional fuck. Alcohol is high but somewhat blended. A little grapefruit in there but not much. Expected more from my boys at Surly. Still very nice though

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 16fl. can. Orangish colour with a good initial formation of off-white head, with an average lasting. Aroma is fruity, orange peel is present; strong hoppy. Flavour has bittery hints at the beginning, pine and orange traces are present, also it has resin hints. The final is really good with an excellent bitterness with a good persistence and duration in the aftertaste. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 From a can. Solid lacing. Earthy, piney aroma with citrus notes. Thick mouthfeel.  Earthy flavors. 

Update - 2013 version - Pour a lightly cloudy gold.  Aroma of citrus, tropical fruit, sweaty jockstrap, onion and garlic.  Real fresh hoppiness, very dank.  Delicious

Can. Split with and courtesy of Tom. Pours a honey orange with a fat fluffed white head and some spotted sea-foam lacing. Aroma is so unqiue; oniony, fresh pine, bitter blood orange, and some insane peanut brittle. Medium bodied with a chewy, thick, yet soft palate. Flavors run along the hop profile line with some savory, oniony, and subtle earthy peanut butter flavors. I know it sounds odd, but it all works so well. Trust me. This is one hell of an IPA.

Aroma is tons of piney, resinous, and citrus hops - notably grapefruit. Pour is a deep orange with a good sized foamy head. Lots of lacing. Seems to be a perfect amount of carbonation. Taste is no surprise with piney hops and citrus. Finishers with sweet biscuity malt back, before the bitter hop finish 

One of my favorite DIPAs. There is a whole lot going on here I probably didnt do justice to.
Poured from can, golden amber with a very hoppy aroma. Me like! Very well balanced with a nice, full presence on the tongue.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 Nose is all bitter, piney, resinous, dank hops.  Definitely abrasive.  Pours out a deep orange with slightly off white fluffy white foam.  Excellent lacing.  Taste picks up where the nose leaves off.  A blast of piney hops, hints of citrus, a touch of honey malt, then finishes bitter.  Palate is quite nice - creamy and crisp.  Excellent DIPA.

Draft at Churchkey. Amber colored, with a medium sized white head. Aroma was hops, heavy on the hops. Dank. Resin notes in the flavor, with a great hop character, heavy on the malts. Pretty good, but alcohol was a bit much for my palate.

Deep amber pour with a great white head. Cheesy hop dankness, apricot, garlic, and all incarnations of nectar and stone fruit. Big scallion and sweet onion with dank herbal notes and resins nectar. Thick palate with tannic hints in the finish.

Tallboy can.  Ice cold.  Opaque orangish pour with nice white head.  Decent cling left on the glass.  Nose bursts with floral hops and citrus.  Taste follows with a big kick of hops and and a decent malt backbone.  Love it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2012 Poured a hazy golden honey, with a huge off white head. Great lacing and wonderful carbonation. Smells of pine, resin, grass, and just juicy hopiness. Great mouthfeel for a DIPA. Tastes of pine, resin, grass, very little maltiness, with a big bitter finish. This beer just tastes fresh and reminds me of a West Coast IPA. Definitely lives up to the hype.
Sampled at 10th annual beer dig.  Pours a clear amber, whitish head.  Sweet and skunky weedy aroma. Flavor is "red" hops and caramel and delicious. Very great dipa

From notes.  First reviewed 1/21/2011.  Poured from a 16 oz. can into a tulip. 

Out of the can this pours a fairly transparent caramel tangerine color. A huge off-white head practically overflows the tulip, leaving gorgeous lacing on the glass.

A well constructed DIPA is always bursting with hop aroma, and Abrasive is no different. A smooth blend of tropical fruits - I get pineapple and a bit of mango, with softer grapefruit and tangerine as well. The sweetness present is more caramel than candied fruit in nature.

As I gathered from the appearance, the front is caramel malt with some sweetness that balances the soon-to-come hops. Even with a valiant effort, there is no chance the malt holds up. The first few sips are not overwhelming, but as the glass goes on, the hops really dig in. Pineapple, grapefruit, orange zest, tangerine, mango, and a touch of pine are present in that order of dominance.

This drinks extremely light for the style. Abrasive is not abrasive, it drinks extremely smooth. The tongue eventually becomes withered with the paint-stripping hop goodness, but I enjoy that. 

There is no doubt that I could drink this all night, even though my tongue might not have taste buds by morning. This is an appropriate step up from Furious, which to date is my favorite IPA. There is potential for improvement, but this is a solid offering.

16 oz. can courtesy of a trade with Atom.  Pours a lightly hazed golden amber with a moderate off-white head that lasted through the first two sips and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma that is filled with orange and grapefruit with some caramel notes present as well.  The flavor is malt and caramel that is quickly followed by pine and citrus bitterness.  Not nearly as fruity as the aroma, the focus is clearly on the bitterness.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Solid ale.

Poured from the can to a pint glass: Pours a hazed ruby gold with a healthy sized off white head and terrific lacing.  Nose is massive.  Loads of citrus, mainly grapefruit or tangerine.  Supported by an ample dose of spruce/pine.  The taste reflects the aroma.  Big pine resin that gets overwhelmed by big citrus.  Addictive bitterness, creamy and full-bodied.  A delight of a beer.

Can courtesy of evanlarkin, thanks!  Murky golden brown color, large tan head with good retention.  Aroma is amazing flowery pine.  Taste is resinous pine and bitter lemon with rising bread dough.  Very nice, but lives up to its name.
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2013 Aroma is hop forward with light notes of spices. Nice heavy hop Aromatics, pine and some grass cuttings. Finishes with a nice dry hop. Very easy to drink.

500ml can from bobbypaulson.Ruby tinged amber with an off white head that fades to a film, yet will come back with a slight twirl of the glass. Fresh pine hops, peach, apricot; Moderate carbonation, full body, bitterness that grows throughout, very smooth without being "abrasive" (although when cold was slightly harsh), becomes slightly sweet along with a malty bitterness towards the end

Poured from tall boy can into a tulip.  Pours dark orange with a bit of creamy beige head.  Aroma is a bit of citrus and hops. This reminds me a bit of Expo and Hopslam, maybe just not as sweet or rich.

16 oz can shared at Justins house.  Pours a nice orangy amber hue.  Little to no foam.  Aroma is sharp of pine with citrus hints.  Taste is tangy, and the citrus and pine have changed places.  Really surprisingly subtle and delicious.  Somewhat bitter grapefruit-rind oddness in the mid to late palate.  Still, excellent stuff. The ABV is well hidden though and its a very impressive brew.

16 oz can into a shaped pint glass. Canned on 1/23/2012, exactly one month old.  Huge thanks to ottodyer for throwing this in as an extra!

A - Dark amber body with a massive fluffy off-white head. Looks great.

S - Loads of tropical fruits with a piney finish. Love the mango and papaya notes. 

T - Same as the nose, mango and papaya followed by a piney bitter finish and some light caramel malts. The bitterness is lasting but not overpowering. Mouth feel is a bit light but carbonation is spot on and the high alcohol isnt noticeable. 

O - One of my favorite DIPAs. Surly knows how to make a damn good hoppy beer.

Can. Clear dark orange body, quickly dissapating head. Great, fruity aroma, very hoppy and lively. Taste is astringent hoppily dry, in a good way. Earthy, robust malts. Next to this being a highly pleasant beer it is also safe to consume in nearly every circumstance: with a can like this people will be thinking youre knocking down a can of energy drink. Thankfully, that wont be the case...

Can:
Medium pretty vast white head on top of a clear darker orange colored beer.
Smell loats of hops and fresh fruit, peach, pine, cactus, pine apple, citrus, resin, somelight light sweet and light sweaty.
Taste is a good mix of hops (!) and its good bitter and less fruity character and the grains like barley (malts).
A good mix of hops; citrus, bitter, floral and fruit; abricot, pine, light grapefruit, peach, light barley malted sweaty, good balanced bitterness.
The peach seems to come out even better after a while. Very nice (peach) hop bitterness.
Nice bitter hop fruity aftertaste with a light dry touch to it.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel (almost silky), full body and a creamy texture.
Very interesting brew, love to buy this shit in cans in your local supermarket! What a treat!
Warming, fresh and well balanced.
