Can, thanks to mora2000, orangish color with white bubbly foam, aroma is fresh piney hops, citrus, flavor is oranges and pineapples with a good caramel malt

canned 12/20/2010. Drank 1/14/2011.  Big thanks to Lushawn for a can.  Now send me some more!  Smells pretty damn dank..dry, vibrant, and piney with floral citrus shadowing.  Loving that smell.  Slightly hazed amber body, off-white head.  Dry, piney hop flavors balanced with just the right amount of sweetness to bring out some lovely candyish citrus hop flavors.  Very focused..not exceptionally bitter at all really, yet loaded with hop flavor.  Body is nicely able to completely avoid being syrupy, and the alcohol is completely masked.  This is an extremely accomplished DIPA, very focused on pure hop flavor without ever getting syrupy or overly sweet nor distractingly bitter. Very very nice.

Amber pour.  Smells like pine, resinous hops extract and bright fresh hops.  Resin, grapefruit and pine needles with just a touch of light malt.  Softly toasty on the palate with a little bit of cookie dough malts through the middle.  Damn awesome IIPA.

Tap, pours s beautiful orange color with a quick to disappear head. Huge, beautiful hop aroma with a citrus/pine nose. Loving it.  Upon tasting, I get kicked in the face with the same citrusly pine flavor but this off, odd wet hay finish that Im not too keen on. Good offering by surly but not even close to the best.

My second of four cans thanks to tytoanderso. Canned 17 days before drinking. Maybe a little bit less fresh than I like my Pliny, but not bad considering its coming across country. Pours with a hazy golden body and a firm off-white head that doesnt ever fully leave and gives great lace. Aroma is super dank. Weed, citrus, tropical fruits, pine needles, caramel, candy, mango. All around goodness. Flavors of tropical fruit, table sugar, caramel, mango, pine, melon, citrus, grapefruit. Probably the best non-West Coast IIPA that I have ever had. Lively bubbles. Properly dry. Lingering fruity-hop-goodness. Much more hope flavor than bitterness. This is how a DIPA should be made. If I could pick up a sub-3 week old 4 (or 6) pack of this every week I would (even as a compulsive ticker).

Not quite as good as bottled PtE (my standard when fresh) of the same freshness level, but still one hell of an amazing Big IPA! Thats a HUGE complement!

I had the pleasure to share a 4-pack with friends on New Years, and we were all left clamoring for more. Lovely orange color and perfect head with an assault of hop aromas, with pine and citrus at the forefront. A stinky hop-bomb dream. The citrusy, hoppy flavors from start to finish made my finish to 2010 a night to remember.

Thanks to chewy08rx for sending this extra can from my want list. 

The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. The aroma screams Double IPA. I get a ton of resiny and pine hops, as well as some orange citrus and something that resembles cat piss  but in a very good  way. Definitely a funky, hoppy DIPA.

The flavor is similar and just as good. I get a lot of orange citrus hop notes as well as some pine notes. The flavor is not quite as dank as the aroma, but it is still a ridiculous hop bomb. There is a bit of a biscuit malt backbone, but this beer is all about the hops. Medium bitterness, but the bitterness is not overbearing. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. An outstanding Double IPA. One of the best I have been fortunate enough to drink.

A hazy, orange-brown pour with white head.  The aroma has a lot of pine, but also a hint of caramel.  The medium body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste is bitter on sides and back of the tongue, but on top it stays semi-sweet.

(16oz can, courtesy of Mora2000)  Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, and weed.  Flavor of pineapple, caramel malt, citrus, herbs, and pine with a bitter finish.

2010 version. I have heard that there was a slight difference from this years to last, not sure what those differences were, but I enjoyed this beer very much. Light carb throughout, with a sweet, citrusy aroma. Mouthfeel is a slightly syrupy sweet citrus as the aroma, but melds into a deliciously hoppy pine twang. Seems like the earthy pine sticks with you as aftertaste for quite some time, which I love. And holy cow the 9%.. whats not to love. Good color, good aromas, good flavor, great aftertaste, even an awesome can / logo. My favorite Surly offering.

Can courtesy Mora2000. Clear light orange color with a light bit of bubbles. Aroma is heavy hops.  Lots of sap, hops, earth and spice on the nose. Flavor is sticky hops and sap. Finishes with pine and christmas trees. Good.

Off orange color w/ a full thick dense white head with good lacing and some light visible carbonation.  Great Aroma!  Tons of deliciously fruity hops, some strawberry, tropical fruits, touch of floral notes, and some nice sweet sugars and other sweetness in there.  Palate is full well coated and finishes very dry.  Great hoppy flavor w/ a pretty big malty backend reminiscent of a great american barley wine.  Theres a light graham cracker in there and lots of fruity floral hop notes.  I really enjoyed this one.

[Can] Pours clear reddish-amber with a nice off-white head. Aroma is huge, quite sweet (some honey), with grassiness, citrus notes and peach. Taste is exploding with juicy tangerine up front, which gives way to dominating malt. Average mouthfeel, smooth, slightly dry finish. Overall, Im really torn about this beer. The aroma is very nice, and the taste was far too sweet, but I do like the tangerine. Not overly complex, not great, not worth the price, but pretty decent.

Amber color out of the can with a foamy off white head that left sheets of lace on the glass.  Pinching grassy, hop resin nose.  Tons of hops in this beer with deep resin, essence of grapefruit rind, and grass.  If they made a hop flavored Jolly Rancher candy, this is what it would taste like.  Not as citrusy as many DIPAs, but it is a damn hoppy beer.

NOTE: This review was merged from my original 16 Grit review.

On tap at Piece Pizza in Chicago.

A: Dark amber color with a good white head and some pretty good lacing.

S: Lots of hops of the citrus/tropical variety. A good, sweet malt backbone. Quite balanced in this regard.

T: Again, definitely balanced with some caramel, brown sugar, and perhaps the tiniest hint of molasses. This goes along with the overriding taste of citrus and tropical hops.

M: Pretty creamy and fairly heavy without too much alcohol.

D: Very drinkable. The complexity continues to invite sip after sip.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2011 Rerate. 16 oz. can thanks to CLevar.  Golden brown, nice head. The aroma is WOW big massive tropical fruits. Buckets of pineapple, mango, citrus, very grassy. This is an amazing overhopped unbalanced aroma showcasing all that is hops. I get a picture of a wooden bowl in my mind with tons of luscious tropical fruits within sitting in the sun. The taste is like grapefruit juice, tropical fruits. I have never tasted a beer that was so much like grapefruit juice. Ode to the hops.

16oz can courtesy of beeranddogs. Pours a clear orange with a towering, creme head. Huge lace and infinite retention. Nose is not fresh hoppy but not stale hoppy, strawberry pancake syrup either. There is some candy corn, maple syrup,   Taste is spicy, sweet, fruit punch, floral and herbal hoppy, loaded with honey, mint, butterscotch. Body is chewy, bitter, thick. Definitely not a hop bomb. Never devolves into an astringent, cloying mess. Even not ultra fresh, it has held itself together fairly nicely.

Can: &nbsp Fiery amber, moderate to large frothy off-white head, nice lacing, light carbonation. &nbsp High octane hop tea is what I would call this aroma. &nbsp Heavy citrus presense on the tongue, sweet but not cloying, with a big background of tea leaves and hops. &nbsp Its not very bitter, but it feels big. &nbsp Sweet citrusy malty with a big hop tea like background. &nbsp Very well balanced between the malts and hops. &nbsp Too easy to drink, really. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Lingering citrus sweetness, background of hop tea. &nbsp Amazingly smooth. &nbsp Not as thick and malty as I like, but this one is very well balanced and probably one of the better IIPAs I have had in a long time. &nbsp Recommended.

16oz can courtesy of skyview. thanks, bob! pours a very nice, pale, orange-gold with a thick, creamy, eggshell head leaving drippy rings of lace. aroma is fantastic with huge, fresh, citrus hop notes of orange, pink grapefruit, and lime zest with a massive tropical fruit background of pineapple, frozen peaches, and passion fruit and just a hint of toffee. flavor is great as well with the sweet, juicy tropical fruit notes of pineapple, mango, passion fruit, and apricot coming to the forefront ahead of citrus flavors of tangerine and pink grapefruit with just enough sweet, slightly nutty, caramel malts to add balance. palate is on the heftier side of medium bodied with a creamy mouthfell, solid carbonation, and a long, bitter, tropical fruit finish. overall, a fantastic and surprisingly tropical dipa. big ups to bob for getting this one to me fresh!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2011 Can.  From Notes.  If you like hops, this beer is for you.  Pours a clear golden amber with a diminishing head.  Aroma is all about the hops...hard pressed to really find anything else there.  Maybe a bit of caramel/crystal malt.  Flavors start with hops, and finish with hops, with the same minor malt tones picked up in the aroma.  Hop resins coat the tongue from first sip to last.  A decent beer, somewhat one dimensional.  
EDIT: Had the 10 version on tap at Stubs, a bit better than last year. (7, 5, 7, 4, 16)

1 pint can courtesy of ncmussell. Thanks. pours a translucent copper color with a medium white head that soon recedes to a fine film and shows some lacing. The aroma was soap, pine and caramel malts. The flavor was biter hops forward with some oranges, more soap, pine resin and malts. The palate was full and smooth with soft carbonation. The finish was short, dry and clean. Overall: A very tasty concoction, but perhaps just a bit too long past its prime. Ill make a note to re-rate sometime in the future.

Can courtesy of Nate.  Poured into a pint glass.  This reminds me of another brew I had recently, but I cant seem to put my finger on it.  Taste-wise this is a very likeable beer.  I only wish I had another can.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share! Pours very pale orange. The aroma is sweet, citric, and reminds me of earl gray tea. The flavor has honey, lemon , grapefruit, candy, tea, and a long bitter finish. Not bad for an IIPA in a can.

Canned. Thanks to the Epeeist. Orange orange with lasting poppy bubbling off-white head. Aroma is floral pungent almost cleaning supply like with a little butterscotch and sticky citrus but not that stinging nose opening citrus, more subtle. Flavor follows suite with huge sticky resiny pines and chewy offensive (maybe abrasive) hops.

Pours a deep orange witha  good head and good lace. The aorma is lots of floral and citrus hops along with a bit of onion. The flavor is big and grape-fruity with some onion and citrus rind bitterness. Not really sweet but more floral sweet, if that makes any sense. Nice beer indeed.

RBSG 2010. Poured a hazy copper color with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate to heavy complex earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish that was long lasting. This is a standout can beer.

16 oz. can poured a hazy golden amber with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of pine, pink grapefruit, apricot, tangerine and cookie. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, pink grapefruit, apricot, tangerine, pine and light earthiness with a smooth dry lingering bitter fruity finish.

Can shared by a friend. Clear gold/orange pour with a medium off-white head. Aroma of citrus, pine sweet malt and grass. Flavor starts with orange and grapefruit, turns to sweet malt, moves on to grass and finishes with spicy hops.
Wow, Im used to liking Surlys, but this is special. A joint aroma and flavor assault. Citrus and pine, malt and earth, fruit and floral, even some sweet Carmel with a nice bitter dry finish.

Shared at a local BA Tasting  Clear amber, white creamy head.  Intense floral and pine aromas warm to soft undercurrents of earthy sweet malt.  Bitter grapefruit and lemon hop assault round out with hints of nutty earth and light caramelized malt.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bitter finish.  All hop heads need only apply here as the name of this beer rings true

500 ml can thanks to Eric! Pours a deep copper hue with a medium white head. The aroma is pure citrus, peaches and oranges. The flavor is great; only slightly bitter, mostly a full on assault of citrus hops, oranges, massive and delicious. A fluffy creamy mouthfeel. Well done.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Rerated 3/23/2012: I upped the score a few notches. I love this hoppy beast (yes, better than hopslam).
=================================== tap at City Pages Beer Fest 2010 and in a can from South Lyndale Liquor. Sweet malt and citrus hop aroma. Quite hoppy, but not as bitter as Surly Furious. Abrasive has a nice balance of sweet malt and citrusy hops which mask the 9% alcohol hiding in the basement cellar. On tap was by far the best, but from the can was still very good...then again, everything is better on tap!

Can shared by guyinchicago at the RBSG Grand Tasting. Thanks! Pours a clear copper color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of citrus and earthy hops with slightly nutty malty notes. The taste is leafy, herbal hops with some citrus and caramel. Medium bodied. Nice.

Shared by MrPickles - Pours clear amber with a very small white head. Aroma is grapefruit, but not terribly sour or hoppy. A little boozy and spicy, but not overly hoppy. Taste is light bitter grassy hoppiness, with honey and a touch of caramel. Decent grassy hops on the finish. Fairly watery and thin with a bit a slickness. Expected a bigger blast of hops, and the sweetness was a little too much.

Can from Secret Santa Summer 10.  Pours an orange-amber color with a thick khacki head.  Thin layer of retention, spotty lacing.  The aroma shows orange peel, tangerine, citrusy hops, and some underlying caramel and resin.  This has a creamy toffee/dough malty backing to the flavor with plenty of citrus hops, tea-like notes and a little resin.  Quite a bit of tropical fruit adds plenty of sweetness with bitterness showing in the finish to counter that.  Pretty good.  A little heavy on the malt for my liking within the style but it doesnt prevent this from being rather tasty.

Can. Pours medium orange/amber. Thin off-white head, solid lacing. Nose is big hops, sweet honey malt, bergamot tea, spicy hop notes are apparent as it warms. Flavors are broad and spicy, rather tea-like, plus orange, grapefruit, pine. More an American Strong than an IIPA.

nice deep amber colour. Not much head. Great aroma . Very hopy. Notes of tea, but it works in this one. Nice lacing. Very creamy mouth feel. Nice aroma very bold with a light floral softness. Very complex and still  very drinkable this is a nice IPA with a very unique character. Notes of tea and vanilla gives this beer great complexity.
Smells very heavily of hops. very clear, not much head/lacing/colour. Very strong hop flavour. Very bitter. It lasts a long time on the tounge. Great hop flavour, its just too single minded.

Tasted from can obtained from a trade.  Pours clear amber orange with a huge white head that is frothy and rocky with excellent retention.  Nose is bitter and citrus hops with a great malt backbone and just a hint of bread and yeast.  Flavor is bittersweet up front with some caramelization on the middle along with pineapple and other tropical fruits.  The hops come in with light lemon and bitterness on the back.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a beautiful tropical fruit and bitter finish.  This is a first class DIPA.

Can, I love that...Pours a hazy amber with an off white head. The head has good lasting and laces well.  Aroma is good with a nice sweet hoppiness and hints of citrusand spruce.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is good, a nice mild bitterness. Has a medium to full body.  A real good finish and an awesome aftertaste.  This is a real good beer, if you get the chance drink it.

Picked up at DLD thanks to skyview and shanago pours dark  golden with a reddish hue slightly hazy with a thick whippy head that clings to glass aromas are of pine and citrus hops with a malty back bone taste is sweet and abbrasive

Thanks footbalm for the can!! It pours golden (lighter than Furious?) with a small, disappearing white head. The aroma is malty with caramel, toffee, and some fruity, tropical hop oils. The flavor is very sweet with lots of toffeeish and caramel flavors with tropical fruit and peach finishing it off nicely. Very thick and sticky mouthfeel. Good flavor, but not as big of a hop punch as I thought it would be.

Surprise beer from barleyPops - thanks Dad!!!  Light, clear orange pour with a frothy white head; lacing sticks to the side of the glass all the way down.  strong citrusy aroma.  resinous hops  and sticky sweet malts dominate, some toffee and caramel as well.  very malty.  creamy, full-bodied mouthfeel for an IIPA. very tasty beer!!

Bonus beer from Kbutler.  Very tasty IIPA.  Pours a lightly hazed glowing orange with a big frothy off white head that left behind some sticky lacing.  Tones of citrus fruits and sticky pine with some semi sweet caramel malts in the back ground.

can thanks to Tharreld poured into a big snifter glass.  pours a deep orange with a big 3 finger fluffy white head.... nice retention at about 1 finger throughout most of the glass.  huge citrus hop nose with some pepper notes.  medium to big mouthfeel with tons of grapefruit, orange and slight banana notes.  some nice caramel malt tones give it a bit of support, but overall this is a hop bomb!  big bitter finish with more citrus notes and some lingering malts.  excellent IIPA in a big can!

Tasted 6/17/10.  16oz can.  Filtered with a golden hue.  Trace head.  Total grapefruit aromatics with a faint malt backbone.  Full bodied and a total hop bomb.  Big emphasis on the grapefruit hops with a side of sweetness.  Delicious!

Poured from a 16oz. can into a snifter glass.  Has a nice orange/reddish/copper color with good head retention and high carbonation.  Lots of citrus hoppy aroma with some nice caramel and toffee notes.  Very malty taste.  Caramel malts take over in flavor with some citrus hops and alcohol in the end.  Very creamy mouthfeel with some hop bitterness.  Me like!

I love Surly cans the do make my day and the can do an IPA.

Can pored into a strait pint glass produced a nice two finger white head that lasted a while and the trailed of to a great lace. The body had a beautiful apricot colored hue to it. You got some great fresh citrus hops aromas from the glass as you held it to your lips.
The flavor was nicely balanced for a DIPA not a west coast one for sure. The grapefruit bitter was blended with a orange sweetness. It reminded me of a tropical drink and it was quite refreshing. It had a medium feel to it with a ton of carbonation. A great drinking DIPA I would have loved a six pack of this brew but was thankful for the one.

Serving type: can

Canned sample- pours a glowing tangering, slight haze, minimal head. Nose- ripe tropical fruit rinds, some pine, sweet cookie malts. Taste- hop forward as expected, thick resiny hop feel, spicy and sweet.  Malt adds mostly a sweetness aspect to it, as this is all about the hops.  Fairly thick creamy body with moderate carbonation. Quite easy drinking which is very dangerous.  A four pack would slide down nicely, and likely lead me to being quite abrasive to those around me...

This poured a bright golden yellow with a fluffy white head. Aroma was lots of citrus fruits, peach and grapefruits. Flavor was basically hop water, no malt to back it up at all, which is a good thing, loaded with citrus notes and fairly bitter. Another winner from Surly

Can from Guerde. Thanks guy! Depending how its held, it poured amber, copper or ruddy copper. The head was substantial and foamy. The hop aroma could anesthetize a pachyderm. The flavor starts resin, goes floral and permits a little malt to seep out. The finish is harshly, scratch that, abrasively bitter. Damn its good.

from a 16 oz. can and poured into my gold rimmed snifter.  picked up for me in the TC by a friend.  Im a sucker for hoppy beers, so was thrilled to have a chance to try this one.  citrus aroma, but nothing overpowering.  pours a honey gold with spotty lace.  a sweet caramel backbone with "some" hop bitterness.  a solid and enjoyable beer, but does not quite live up to its name.

16oz can acquired through trade with matSciGuy, thanks Levi! Poured into standard pint glass. Poured a rich golden color with a small white head. Aroma of hops hops and more hops, very piny. Taste of sweet caramel malts with a robust hoppy finish on the pallet. Best IPA out of a can I have had thus far.

Canned sample via and shared with oakbluff. Pale orange in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of grainy pale malts, and oily and citrusy C-hops. Fairly assertive malt and oat flavors mix with the strong grapefrut, tangerine, and pine resin notes. A hoppy beer, but not overly bitter, especially for a IIPA. Softer in the mouth than expected. Good overall, but I prefer Furious.

16 oz can.  Clear copper with a foamy white head.  Nose is pine, pineapple, pine cones and brown sugar.  Slick, medium body with a buzz.  Taste is caramelized grapefruit, tangerine peel and toffee.  Finishes resiny with bitter pine and spearmint.

Can thanks to mashmaster. Pours a orange color with a thin white head. Has strong smell of tangerine. Has a citrus taste and is very oily. Doesnt have nearly as much of a bitter after taste as I thought it would.

On tap at SmallBar. Pours a crisp golden clean clear orange color. Nice creamy head that disappears into a thin off white ring. Head forms quickly when agitated in glass. Head clings to glass like soap. Sweet citrus aromas with some pine. Hoppy but well balanced with sweet malt character and apricot notes. Full bodied and very drinkable. Alcohol well hidden. Refreshing. Good job on this one.

16oz can shared by footbalm, thanks again 
Appearance: Clear amber with a nice off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Citrus, fruits and  pine
Taste: Citrus, fruity and some malts 
Great beer, awesome aroma and flavor. No bitterness, just nice fruity and citrus hops.

Orange-gold pour with a white head.  Big citrus, melon and pine aroma with some sweet toffee and biscuit, a hint of floral character.  Grapefruit, bubblegum, melon, honey and pine flavor with some sticky sweet caramel.  Oily, medium-full body with moderate carbonation.

2010 Can - Thanks tytoanderso!!! - Pours a clear orange with a medium beige head...aroma is pitchy and piney, caramel and citrus peel, very florall...flavour is similar, nice citrus oil bitterness, caramel, tons of tropical fruit, pineapple and tangerine....finish is sticky and malty, with a hop bite that onle lingers for a short while...pretty tasty stuff!

A dark golden color. Bold citrus aroma to the nose. A full bodied beer in flavor leaving you with a great bitter aftertaste. You can taste the alcohol a little but with the strong hoppy and citrus flavors it is not bad like some double IPAs I have tried before. This is a great beer so try it if you havent already

16oz can pours a totally transparent, orange amber with one ring of white head.  Nose has pine cones, orange zest, caramel, lemons, some flowers.  Flavor is sweet, caramel, cookie dough, grapefruit, orange zest, pine.  Full bodied, bitter finish.

*Previously reviewed on-tap at 16 Grit.

Big thanks to my MN homie, younger35, for the hookup. Poured from 16oz can into my GI pint glass.

A - Pours reddish/gold copper color with a white head. A fingers-wroth of foam disipiates down to a thin cap on top with some bubbles here and there and a thicker ring along the sides of the glass.

S - Big hops, sweet malts, citrus, grapefruit. Everything youd expect from a big DIPA from Surly. 

T - Piney citrus hops with not too much malts. Im so glad this isnt overly sweet. Im so tired of DIPAs that are huge malt-bombs. This one has the huge hops with a nice subtle sweetness on the finish. Nice sweet orange finish with a touch of bitterness.

M - Medium bodied, light carbonation, crisp and refreshing.

D - A very well-done DIPA by Surly. Probably one of the best I can remember in the past few months. I only have a few cans left, but Ill make sure theyre gone before it looses the wonderful hop & malt mix.

Note: I prefer this one to Furious.

A: The beer is amber in color with great clarity and a massive cream colored head on top which sticks to the edge of the glass.

S: A hop bomb if Ive ever smelled one! Very reminiscent of Sculpins aromas. A ton of tropical fruit, especially pineapples and mangos along with plenty of juicy citrus. No malt to be found.

T: The sweet tropical fruits are really the main attraction here as well. The pineapple and mango provide a nice sweetness, along with some peaches. There is plenty of juicy grapefruit and pine on the finish to give the beer a great bitterness.

M: Medium in body with a low to moderate carbonation and a really crisp finish to the beer.

D: I say it everytime I have a Surly beer, and Ill say it again: awesome! These guys really have a good thing going and Im glad to have some more of this one in the fridge.

Translucent amber. Small white head. Aroma of big ruby red grapefruit and sugar. Flavor is much more outstanding than what would be expected by the nose. Huge florals, sweet rub red and grass. Wonderful, and fresh.

Thanks to hopdog for sharing this Got N Trade beer.  Pours a mostly translucent golden amber with a medium bubbly off white head.  Aroma of resiny hop notes, lots of pine and a touch of grapefruit, some light caramel and hints of toffee.  Flavor of resiny hops, kind of sweet maltiness, caramel, grapefruit and herbal notes.

Pours a dark, glowing orangey amber and topped with a fair amount of white head from the 16oz. can courtesy of arminjewell (thanks, buddy!): Luscious aroma of ripened tropical fruits, grass, chunks of pink grapefruit meat, and an undertone of caramel malts. Flavors of straight up citrus- tangerine, orange, grapefruit, and maybe some mango/pineapple/peach smoothie. Lots of fresh florals and medicinal herbs take the palate accompanied with some pine and resinous hops. Pretty malty and sweet, not in a turnoff-ish way, though I wouldnt say its dangerously drinkable. Aftertaste of creamy butter. Sticky and soapy throughout. Wishing there was more hoppage action to balance this sucker out. Drinkability: All sweet up-front, but slowly turns into a silent killer. I dont trust it, kid, I just dont trust it. Pairing: Coconut creme de fraise over red velvet cake. Rebuy: Probably. #442 on 07052010, DG.

Can from arminjewell. Thanks Armin! Pine and tropical fruits dominate this beer in a really great way. Pours almost amber in color with two fingers of long lasting white head. Strong bitterness, slick hop oils and mango permeate this delicious brew. Finishes almost sweet from hop oils.

A: Pours a light golden hue. Tall foamy head, good retention, like a lace bomb exploded in the glass.

S: Aromas of booze, pine, citrus, green grass, and chemical solvent. Harsh without being off putting.

T: Boldly hopped for sure. Very much citric, with lemon zest and pith included. A bit bitter for sure. Hints of more sweet and resinous pine along with floral green hops. The booze is there, but not in too big of a way. The aroma says this one is hopped as hell and I am sure there is a ton of malt there trying to provide balance but it really dont work (not a bad thing). It is hop forward and pretty damn good to be honest.

M: On the fuller side of medium in body, fairly full for the style. Bold and bitter.

D: Not the most drinkable, but still solid. It is tasty and one I enjoyed putting back while in the pool on a hot May evening.

pours amber with a bright white head and good lace.  really great intensely piny and hoppy nose.  smells like a very enticing pine forest mixed with lemon peels.  Not quite as bitter as one would expect as it is pretty well balanced with the malts, which gives it just a hint of a sweet characteristic.  Very nice and quite tasty.

A rich citris aroma with an almost cloudy orange tint, and nice foamy head.  Taste as it smells with sweet citrus with a more mild malt backround.  Supprisingly smooth for its name and ABV.  All in all another great Surly limited release.

Sipping on this one as I type... poured from the can into my Sam Adams Perfect Pint glass with some good frothy white head with decent lacing.

The aroma is remarkably fruity and leads perfectly into a well balanced fruity/sweet/bitter flavor.  This is an incredibly drinkable DIPA and is a VERY close rival to Hopslam (my other favorite in the style).  All in all one of the best beers Ive had recently - cannot wait to get more - this one will be a staple in my fridge anytime Im lucky enough to be able to have it.  PURE CLASS.

DELICIOUS and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

16oz. can, with a big thanks to tytoanderso for the cans!  Pours a clear orange golden with a large frothy off-white head that leaves nice lacing as it recedes.  Aroma is a big dose of hops, including grass, earth, pine/resin, citrus and some rind, along with a hint of caramel.  Flavor is sweet on the outset, followed by nicely balanced hops and malt, with spice, pine, grass/earth and more citrus rind and a mild lingering bitterness and some residual warmth.  Nice stuff, if not a touch sweet, but still a very nice DIPA.  Thanks again Ty!

Amber pour with a white head. Aroma is wow-hops x 2. Citrus, floral, and even some malt. Taste is super. Creamy, malt, pine, citrus, damn good beer. A good enough beer to pick the family up and move to Minnesota.

16oz can. Slightly greasy, resinous and plastic aroma at first. Oily hop structure when cold gives way to slight fusel and chemical aromas upon warming. Sure... theres a bit of pine resin and citrus meat but malty sweetness and the most bizarre scent of engine oil really take away on the nose for me. Pours bright amber/gold topped by a thin but creamy eggshell white head that leaves spotty lace. Slightly underattenuated malt body gives initial impressions of sweeter sticky caramel and toffee. The greasy hops dont really come into play until near the finish where they coat the back sides of the tongue with a plastic-y resinousness. Medium bodied throughout. Average to low carbonation with a dry, corn-husk-ish finish. Theres really not a whole hell of a lot going on in this beer. 
Sweet malt... check.
Oily and one-dimensional hop profile... check. 
Slight hints of buttery diacetyl... check
Out of balance alcohol on the finish... check.

Can from a DLD trade.  Thanks, random person!

Pours to a nice amber with a perfect white head.  Nose is very strong, and full of citrus and piney hops.  The taste is a medley of hop perfection.  Very fruity, like a succulent mango,  robust with flavor but not as bitter as the name "Abrasive" would imply.  I imagine the folks at Surly loaded up the late hop and dry hop additions to achieve this hop-heads dream beer.  This isnt the driest of the style, but I think the lingering sweetness adds something special to its flavor profile.

This is damn fine beer.  If this was available in Ohio, Id be a regular customer.

Thanks to Bob for the cans!  Poured clear, medium honeyed brown with a creamy cap of beige head.  The aroma was super juicy with pineapple, mango, and grapefruit over a sweet caramel base.. the hops really pop, and I think I got lost for a while in there.. loved it!  The flavor was equally juicy, showcasing more of the pineapple and grapefruit, picking up pine and fresh grassy character.. sweet, lightly-toasted caramel and lesser honey supported very well.. plenty of residual bitterness on the long finish, with just the right sweetness to support it.  Medium-bodied and resiny on the palate with a thick, coating flow to it.. spicy, bitter, and engaging.. excellent stuff!

Bottle tasting at DLD. Youll have to forgive me for my less than thourough tasting notes... a drunk taster with a destroyed palate does not, a proficient rater, make!
"Double IPA from a can... cant stop giggling while I drink." <--- LOL! Official tasting notes, near the end of the day.  Evidentally canned IIPA is a riot, but a damn damn fine beer.  Once again I am put in my place by Surly and their canned masterpeices.  Still havent gotten over canned craft, but they are quickly schooling me.

Great googly moogly this beer is delicious.  Superb aroma of fresh tropical fruits, pineapple and mango.  Far from the name, the flavor is not scorchingly hoppy, rather it is very lightly sweet with a creamy mouthfeel.  Dynamite.

Can at DLD thanks to translucent on BA, who hooked me up with a whole 4-pack in a trade, 3 of which I popped open at DLD to share.

This is a great lookin one. Pours hazy light amber with a nice-sized whitish head that lasts. Good lacing.

Aroma is really solid. Very citrusy hop profile - orange, tangerine, and grapefruit, maybe some tropical notes - as well as a little sweet malt.

Flavor is a little maltier than the great west coast IPAs, but still very hop-forward. Being from the east coast originally, I dont mind the malt. Big citrus, orange and grapefruit mainly, with some slight pineapple and earth. Just a little sweet caramel.

Excellent mouthfeel: mildly dry with medium body and lots of hop resins.

Very drinkable. A great DIPA overall. Hopefully Surly brews more of this one.
50 cl can, Fargo, ND, USA. Deep golden/amber colour, astringent fresh aroma of pine resin. Floral in the mouth, fresh and flowery with a bit of soap.

16 oz. can shared by shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn (and Kylie for grabbing these in the Twin Cities).  Pours a somewhat cloudy gold color with a finger-thick white head.  Awesome aroma, so herbal and fresh, with hops, marijuana, pale and caramel malts, and not a whole lot else.  Simple and near-perfect.  Flavor cant live up to that, with more fresh herbal hops, pine, citrus, and a ton of caramel and pale malts.  Malty mouthfeel, with above-average carbonation and a bitter finish.  I wish the hops came through in the flavor like they did in the nose, but not the case in this malt bomb.  Im giving the nose the slight edge over the Furious, but the rest cant live up to that incredible IPA.

Can smell the very fragrant hops a mile away. todd is one of the premier hoppers in the nation. Pretty much your near perfect Imperial. Big resiny  pine hopping,a rather large malt presence,almost has a sweetness to it, this is the balance everyone seems to scream for, if thats your style this is a 20 for you. For me ,but a little to malty to be among my favorites

UPDATED: APR 30, 2010 Can supplied by a very generous BA and thanks to Skyview for hooking me up with a couple cans too. Pours clear dark orange with one finger white head. Aroma was impressive. Loaded with dank hops and tons of citrus. Flavor was loaded with bitter hops, but lacking all the citrus and a good malt back bone. Abrasive is a good name for this brew as if you dont like a ton of bitter hops than this one might not be for you. Solid beer but a bit of a disappointment based on past ratings.
Re-rate: 4/30/10. Will give this a second shot at my palate was probably destroyed on DLD. Pours clear golden orange with one finger off-white head. Aroma is still outstanding with  fresh grapefruit and other citrus, pine, tropical fruits, and tons of hops. Flavors of grapefruit, citrus, bitter hops, nice sweet malt, and some peach and mango flavors. Does not have the overload of bitter hops I remember vividly from DLD. Either this beer is fading or could be from different batches. Either way I found it much more enjoyable this time. Solid DIPA for sure.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2011 Can bored into wine glass.  Clear light copper orange with a big foamy tan head. Not as hoppy as I was expecting.  They should have doubled the hops but kept the malts the same.  Or maybe drinking a dipa a week after its released is too long to wait.  Seems more like a light bodied hoppy barleywine with the booze presence, or maybe thats what dipas are these days.   



rerate.   better than i remembered.   pleasant bitter, pine, hoppiness.   dry.   really good DIPA.

Pours deep amber Orange with an off white head. Aroma of citrus and floral hops with caremal malt. Taste is grassy, grapefruit up front but caramel malt quickly overtakes most hop flavor. The hop juice and malt make it sligtly sweet but not cloyingly so.  Either the hop profile has faded already or it was designed to be very balanced but overly so I think. Hides the alchohol nicely for 9%.  I was hoping for a more hop forward dipa.

Huge thanks to skinnyguy for sending this my way.  Amber pour with a nice sized off white head. Aroma is grass,  grapefruit, diacetyl, and caramel.  Flavor is up front caramel malt,  butter, grapefruit rind, toffee,  and grass.  Bitter finish,  good carbonation.  Tasted old less than a week after release...not my thing.
Decent amount of hop aroma but my first taste gave me a strong impression of butter (Diacetyl?).  All I can focus on now is the harsh and lingering foul aftertaste of butter.

Can.  Pours orange with a small white head.  Mostly citrus hops in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet with apricot, but balanced nicely with bitter grapefruit flavors from the hops.  Some alcohol flavor is present, too.  Loads of lacing left on my glass.  This is a solid, but disappointing, beer that doesnt live up to the hype in my opinion.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2011 (tap at Acadia) Pours orange with a thin white head that leaves good lacing on the goblet.  Aroma is full of crushed mint, grapefruit, celery (not digging the vegetal presence), some cedar (Humidor?), and shades of tropical juiciness.  Slightly herbal and resinous as well.  Taste is rather sweet and very underwhelming, and it was quite difficult to pull out any distinct qualities in the flavor.  Faintly bitter with some grapefruit pith, but the sweetness really dominated everything else.  Alcohol is never present which is a plus.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is restrained.  This beer plays second fiddle to other DIPAs Ive sampled, and at the price point of $16 a 4-pack, Im glad I only tried it once (and only once) on-tap.  Really disappointing.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2010 16 oz. can to snifter. Pour is rich copper with a frothy khaki head. Big floral hops and citrus malty aroma. Taste again big grapefruit and citrus bursts in mouth and sweet creaminess as well. Palate has a nice chaulky sticky feel with a nice dry finish. This is a very, very hoppy DIPA lets say this is a dank DIPA. Very well done!

pours a rich yellow-orange under a dense off-white head. Nose is big citrus hops and sweet maltiness. First taste is monstrous citrus hops that is so strong that it comes off actually tasting like orange. The malt gives a great balance of sweetness. Im loving this one. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy on top of the big hop tang. finish has a hint of alcohol with a bit of hop bite. This is a very good beer.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2010 light amber pour with a medium head.
aroma is nice caramel maltiness with a floral and citrus hop presence. 
full malt flavoured body. Nice piney and  juicy fruity hop flavour. Lingering malty sweetness in the finish. 
Sweetness does tend to increase as the brew warms.

growler - thanks to yonkers65 for hooking this up; reddish orange with frothy white head; super fruity, dank aromas of floral and citrus hops; super juicy, sweet and surprising lack of bitterness (in a good way) malty, sticky and quite intense; theres something very unique here with the in your face sweetness; an amazing double IPA
Very hoppy aroma mostly citrus but some flowers.  The body is intensely hoppy as well with a very strong malt backbone and additional pine flavors as well.
Heavy hoppy smell with a touch of citrus and floral.  Taste had a slight citrus to a it with a good malty finish.  The description was right... its abrasive, but in a good way.
Draught at Herbs and Stubbs. Intense alcohol. Lots of malt. Really good beer. Enjoyed this.

Pours an amber copper with a thin white head. Aroma is of sweet pine and floral hops. Tastes very hoppy with hints of pine, earth, citrus, fruits, orange, grapefruit, lemon, mango, and some malts. Bitter hop finish to a delicious brew.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2012 yet again another great super hopy IPA.  pours a murky amber with a clean white head.  Smell is of flowers and citrus.  Taste is that amazing bitter hop taste that smooths out with citrus.  A Great beer.

This years (2012) abrasive was honestly the best IPA Ive ever Had!!!!!  So happy its was very available this season!!!!!!

On tap at Monks House of Ale Repute.  Pours amber with decent off-white head.  Good hoppy citrus nose with some grass notes.  Flavor is really smooth hoppy with a big kick of malt that rounds out the edges of the hops.  Medium body with very nice mouth feel.  A good bite of hops on the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 RERATE 2-15-12: I had a fresher version of this in the can, and I enjoyed it a little more this time. Nice earthy mouthfeel, and overly bitter (in a good way). A total hop bomb, with some maltiness to back it up. OLD RATE: draft at binnys south loop. Pours reddish amber with an off white head. Nice floral and citrus hop aroma. Medium bodied with average carbonation and slight creaminess to the mouthfeel. Malt backbone of caramel and toasted malts countered by an assertive bitterness that adds notes of orange, grass, and grapefruit. Slight resiny finish. Good, but I was expecting much better. 8-4-7-4-14

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2010 [02May10] Can, pours a clear, light gold with off-white foam.  Aroma of citrus and floral hops, grapefruit, and apricot/peach.  Flavor is similar and balanced with caramel malts.  Medium-bodied with a slightly syrupy mouthfeel.  Lightly carbonated.  This seems somewhat different than when I had it on draft as 16 grit. {7/3/7/4/14}

[04Jun09] Draft at Stub & Herbs.  Pours a slightly hazy orange-amber body with off-white head.  Nice aroma of a variety of floral and grapefruit hops, pine, and caramel malts.  Flavor is similar with more of the grapefruit hops coming out.  Very well-balanced with malts to keep the hops in check.  Smooth mouthfeel with a bitter citrus and pine finish. {8/4/8/4/15}
Growler. Thanks, Yonkers! Pours hazy amber with an off-white ring of foam. Sweet pine,  grapefruit and resin aroma. Sweet taste of pine and oranges. This stuff is like drinking fresh hops.

On tap at Stub & Herbs.  Pours clear orange amber with a nice off-white head.  Huge hop aroma, funky pine and floral, with some grapefruit.  Taste is balanced with caramel malt.  Smooth with a nice bitter citrus hop finish.

Draught at the Grumpy Bulldog in Naperville.  Dark copper orange amner with a thin creamy off-white head that leaves a ton of lacing all down the glass in big swathes.  Aroma is very piney and resimous.  Flavor floral and piney hops with a deep rich dank body.  Bitterness is potent but not extreme.  If this had just a bit more vibrant hops it would be amazing.  Full creamy mouth feel.

Draft @ Bavarian Lodge 4/30/09-Pours an orangish amber with a small off white head. Aroma of hops and citrus. Flavor the same with some malt, caramel, and some bitterness. This medium bodied brew was a great tasting beer and well balanced.

Hand bottle shared by iowaherkeye and firmbuttstone. Poured a hazy dark orange color. The head was off white with an orange tint. Attractive aroma of citrus, pine, caramel, orange marmalade, and mango. medium bodied and slightly sweet with moderate bitterness. Lots of fruit juice/orange marmalade in the flavor with subdued caramel and alcohol notes. Delicious.
Tap at Piece Post DLD ... amber copper ... sweet piney hop nose ... big hop front and huge bitterness ... some pine and grapefruit ... but its just bitter.

Woah. On tap at the Bavarian Lodge. Golden orange with nice thick white head. Big, sweet, hoppy aroma. Flavor is a bit on the sweet side, with a ton of citrus, balanced by a huge amount of hops. Bitter, flavorful, delicious hops. Some alcohol and honey in the finish. Creamy, thick mouthfeel. Totally awesome bad ass brew.

[Draft @ Barley House] Poured a dark golden color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of pine, citrus fruits, floral hops, grass, wood, resin, and alcohol.  Taste of citrus fruits, resiny pine, some honey, a bit of tobacco, and a bitter, grapefruit finish, with some dry alcohol as well.

Pours a honey gold with thick white head. Aroma is a mineral wheat hops smell. Flavor is a citrus blend with definite earthy hop notes. A bitter note begins each sip but smoothes out with a very subtle creamy flavor.

On tap @ Map Room. Clear light amber beer, average creamy head leaving lacing; herbal, medicinal aroma; tastes like a hoppier Furious, ending long and bitter. Slightly peaty and spritzy in the mouth, but a little thin. Not a DIPA in the Dradnaught and Maharaja mould, but very drinkable ala Hopsoulution and quite tasty.

Draft at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle. Cloudy, orangey IPA color, sudsy head of bubbles coating the sides of the glass. Smells like an apricot sundaeits-just-that-hoppy! Taste is bursting with with syrupy malts and the fruitier side of American hops. Despite the name, I found this to be quite smooth, until I started to feel a bitter burn on my soft palate. Now the more familiar hop character of grapefruit, pine and an otherwise undefinable snap, like, yanking a big strip off a roll of strapping tape.

On tap at the 8th St. Grill in Minneapolis.  Im not sure what was up with the keg or perhaps the lines, but this beer didnt smell of hops and the taste was just okay.  Judging by the responses here I either got a taste of some spoiled 16 Grit or everyone else I rating on Surlys reputation.  At $9.00 a glass this should be looked into.

Guest tap at Piece and HELL YEAH! Amber pour wtih an off white head.  Tons of hops, fruit, caramel, and MORE HOPS! Grapefruit galore!  Flavor is loaded with grapefruit and some good caramel malt balance.  Great mouthfeel and just a great beer!
Draft at Sheffields. citrusy and aromatic. nice big hop flavor along with some serious bitterness, but enough malt to keep it very drinkable

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2011 An excellent DIPA from a great brewery, poured on tap at the tour deep amber with nice white head.  Flavor was extremely hoppy and bitter, with a nice crisp and easy to drink finish.  Alcohol masked too well with citrus and floral tones, an excellent DIPA.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2010 On tap @ Lunar. Pours faintly hazy burnt orange with a nice white head. Very citrusy and floral aroma with tons of hops. Taste is very enjoyable. Nice and bitter, but not too oily and under-balanced.
hello lover. this was one super tasty beer. citrus aromas. very hoppy with some nice carmelly sweetness to it. really tasty

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2014 Draft at Jerrys. Hazy amber-gold with big, foamy off-white head / Rich, creamy nose of pine, weed, citrus, bread / Medium body, a touch watery, soft, light fruit, lots of bitterness / Flavors of bread, oats, pine, orange, lemon, cream / Not the best Ive had from this fine brewer.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2014 On tap @ Maproom Saturday. Big IIPA! The aroma is intense, strong fresh amarillo hop, you can tell this one is going to have a kick ass bitter hop flavor. The taste is just a suspected, just not too balanced in my opinion. Over done on the bitterness and no much malt backbone. Taste of pine, citrus and fresh hops. A real intense IIPA. Could have let this sit and mellow a bit. But oveall a nice IIPA

Re-Rated - 

Aroma has strong citrus notes. Grapefruit may dominate and offset the bitter feel, but doesnt completely hide the nice hop profile. Body is more full than it initially lets on. Tremendous lacing down the glass. Lovely

Tap @ Maproom.  Pours orange with a white head.  Awesome hoppy aroma, with heavy grapefruit and a little bit of pine.  Great bitter flavor, hops dominate just the way I like it.  Grapefruit and other citrus flavors.  Oily mouthfeel.  Awesome stuff, glad to finally grab a pint.

On tap Firkin Fest 09. Pours a deep orange color, slight sediment, thick foamy head. Flavor is lovely citrusy thick hops and a slightly sugary malt backbone. Notes of citrus fruit, citrus zest, candy sugars, crystal malt. Slightly gritty, I imagine due to the barrel conditioning. Finishes dry and earthy.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 TAP: at the Happy Gnome (St. Paul, MN) on 4.11.09. Pours a gold amber with a heavy white head. Floral hop nose, Big citrus hop flavor, with some malty backing. Great beer.

pours serious amber with thick white head.  nose of heavy hops, grapefruit, floral and pine and a little carmel.  taste just as it smells, floral, grapefruit and lots of hops, quite bitter and woody.  Really good, too bad Surly wont make it again.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2010 Have had numerous times now and need to bring it down. Had fresh at Fountainhead yesterday and feel like there just too much malt character. Im getting a fair amount of C-malts which dont work for me in IIPA. Still good, but not worthy of a 4+.

Draft at Binnys south loop. Pours a mostly clearly amber. Nose is well hopped, tropical fruits, a bit of resin and funky hops. Nothing too over the top. Taste is comparable, very hop-forward with some nice, clean bitterness. Not harsh at all. Lots of fruity notes come through, as does the resiny pine notes. This one is super easy to drink. Good stuff.

on tap at Binnys South Loop, Chicago. pours slight hazy amber with white head. nose is very piney, earthy, melon, and grapefruit hop forward nose. flavors are piney, bitter!, juicy, mango, nice balance here, slightly sweet middle, very tasty.

At Happy Gnome, served in a mini tulip, appearance is clear gold with a minor head.  Aroma is quite citrus like, hops, and sweet.  The flavor is solid citrus IPA with sweetness and lots of warmth.  The palate is rich and delecate.  Overall, nice.

Golden color.  Not my favorite double IPA by any stretch.  I found the hops to be massive, but not so much on the front end.  Theres the usual assortment of citrus flavors on the front end, with well controlled alcohol and a bit of candy sweetness too, but it was really the finish that marked out this beer for me.  It finished with a kind of hop unidimensionality, where it lingers (only moderately bitter) but with an acidic pine flavor that seemed both crass and unwelcome.  The malts here arent doing enough to give this sophistication and subtlety.  I couldnt finish my pour.  I thought in Minnesota we had some chance of avoiding the banal excesses of West Coastism in brewing.  I guess not. (on tap at Muddy Pig, St. Paul)

Draft @ Galway Tribes. Watch out for the teetering bar stools. Amber pour into what appeared to be a water or soda glass? Short off white tannish head? Aroma of zesty citrus,  hops. Mouth is great, with creamy feel and good carbonation. Not @ all the hop bomb I expected. Tastes dominantly citrus with a good malt back. Bitter rind finish, and a buttery breadiness. Balance and drinkability paired with a decent bitter linger redeem this. Not Surlys best. Highly drinkable. Would try again.

On tap at Galway Tribes. Pours a darkish orange with a small fomay head. Aroma is of grapefruit, malt, pine, and caramel. Taste is of juicy citrus, mostly grapefruit with lots of pine and slight caramel. Has a very biscuity malt backbone. Body is medium, and surprisingly buttery. Finish is very acidic, with an alcohol burn. Not nearly as bitter as I had anticipated. Too acidic and buttery to be very drinkable. Good, but dissapointing to a degree.

Pre-tapping sample at Lunar Brewing Co.,Villa Park, IL. Poured a clear, golden amber, with a thick, small bubbled, white head and some solid lacing. The nose was a very pleasant aromatic blend of tangerine, grapefruit, and smooth malt. The flavor added to these some rich, malt sweetness, and a strong but mellow bitterness that followed into the finish and beyond. A very nicely balanced DIPA, almost a carefully aged, big Furious.

12 oz draft poured on tap at The Galway Tribes (Frankfort, Il). A true gem of a find. Pours a lovely fiery amber, well hazed, with touches of orange, a decent offwhitish head that clings to the sides of the glass and laces well. Aromas are powerful: a lovely floral hop bouquet pushing large grapefruit bitterness and zest coupled with orange, moderate tropical fruits of mango, and a sweet balancing malty backbone of carmel and biscuit. Initial has a good body, stepping down a little on harshness, but certainly bringing the taste. Big grapefruity hoppy bitterness coupled with a balancing sweetness. Some tropical fruits lie a little deeper, mango and papaya, florals, and some nice sort of piney resin comes through towards the finish. This doesnt weigh you down, but certainly asserts itself. Finish is bitter, balanced, lovely aftertaste.

16 oz. pour, on tap at Grumpys in downtown MPLS as part of the March 16, 2009 release party along with ElGaucho. Thanks for inviting me! My first thought was this is Furious with a kick.  Very hoppy, very strong, and very very good.  Pours a hazy, dark gold with slight amber. Aroma is citrus and pine. Very aggressive taste of pine. Definite sweet malt hits in the middle balancing out the agressive hoppiness. Medium body. Lively and refreshing in the palate. My thought is this is just as good as Furious but definitely couldnt make this a session beer. (Although I was given a second for free due to a wrong beer making its way to our table and I didnt refuse it!)

L: Thin off white head. Vibrant blood orange. Only a touch of brown. A consistent cloudiness.
S:A bright citrus orange. A sweet floral grassyness comes storming out.
T:A sweet candied blood orange pops out. Slight grapefruit citrus roles in. A caramel bready wheat comes floating through. What really stands out is the blood orange.
M: Nice fat smoothness with a sharp fizz on the back of the tongue.
D: Delicious incredibly balanced beer. The hops still really pop out with being so balanced though. This beer lasted much longer in the growler than I had anticipated. Very good.

Growler via faro99 over here but via faro himself over on thebeerspot.  Pours orange with a tan head.  Nose is sweet and hoppy and overall reminiscent of 90 minute IPA.  Taste is quite nice with a grapefruit citrus punch and a nice bitter piney resin that runs through it.  Its nice to see such a big IPA that maintains a ton of citrus.

In short: A extra-hoppy and highly drinkable 9% IPA focussing on refreshing fruit flavours .  Excellent.
How: Growler at post-EBF 2009 tasting.  Big thansk to Rciesla
The look: Cloudy dark orange body topped by a small off-white head
In long: Nice pungent hoppy nose that is half grapefruits half citrus fruits.  Rather restrained malt backbone with light caramel and residual sugar.  Hops are the stars here with grapefruits, grass, tropical fruits, oranges, citrus fruits.  A little lemony with a light citric touch that makes it even more drinkable.  Relaxed carbonation.  Very bitter but nothing resinous or harsh here, this is a refreshing fruity bitterness.  With a body more rich and a little less sugary sweet this would be a world class IIPA.  But this is great stuff nonetheless.  Kicks more ass than a donkey on acid.

Growler obtained in a trade, shared with some bros.  Pours a an amber body with a white head.  Caramel malt, citrus loads of pine some light grapefruit.  Citrus earthy floral hoppiness.  To bad it was shared next to pliny the younger, never stood a chance.

16 oz. pour, on tap at Grumpys in downtown MPLS as part of the March 16, 2009 release party. This is the new, drier recipe. Pours a hazy, dark gold to light copper or brass color. Great hops aroma features lemon, citrus, pine, and quinine scents. Satisfying, hoppy, decidedly double IPA taste. Very aggressive taste of pine. A hint of fruit sweetness that increases on multiple sips: orange juice, apricot. Long, dry aftertste. Medium body. Lively and refreshing in the palate. Good but not great (and not as good as Furious); a bit of a disappointment. Not as complex as I would have hoped.

Growler.  Pours a very nice golden copper color with a frothy beige head. Very nice lacing and head retention.  The aroma is very nice.  Huge grapefruit/citrus notes and very smooth and inviting.  Flavor tastes like orange juice and grapefruit.  Very hoppy (duh!) but still smooth at the same time.  Easy drinker.  It has a nice, full body to it and its not too heavy.  Overall, very nice...not what I expecting going in but very very good.  I wish I had more!

Growler from KAF, thanks Kyle!  Hope the hops arent like the Furious, where they die after a week.  Clear orange with a short lived 1/2 finger beige head.  Lots of mango and tropical fruit hops with a little bit of grassiness.  Clean caramel malt backbone.  Flavor continues to be mega fruity--usually theres pine somewhere, but not a so much here!  Just loads of fruity hops, as well as some orange.  Bitterness peaks around a 5 in the finish, with the alcohol undetectable.  Low carbonation with a medium-full smooth body.  I wonder how this wouldve been two months ago!  Quite tasty, and glad I got to try this.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Courtesy Beerlando.  Amber color, thin soapy white head.  Strong grassy hop aroma, very earthy, defined malt aroma also.  Strong hop taste, murky bitterness, very lasting aftertaste.  Brash and earthy.

Many thanks to Skyview for a growler of this.  Copper red pour.  Thin head.  Grapefruit, tangerine, mango, and some floral hops.  Balanced and not overly bitter.  Nice smooth palate for the style.  Surly knows what theyre doing when it comes to hop forward brews.  Hopefully this gets brewed again.

Sampled from Growler. I never thought I would get a crack at this one! Poured a medium and cloudy amber color wtih a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of citrus (oranges and grapefruits), pine, floral, tangerines, and sticky. Tastes of the same citrus, pine, caramel, and the same stickiness. Nice and hoppy with a malt balance in the taste. Alcohol content hidden.

Growler, brought to the Stouts tasting. And I mighty fine IPA it was. Orange/copper with white head. Sweet and awesome hops come out of the glass to start you salivating while you smell the beer. Tasted great, nice and hoppy with an awesome sweetness to really nicely balance this beer. Up there as on of the best IIPAs Ive had.


As the story goes this wont be available in Growlers any longer due to Minnesota law changing, sad if its true and made us toast to one of the last Surly 16 Grit growlers to be consumed.

Hand bottle.  Nose of pure hoppiness, fruity, citric and piney with touches of quality grass and a bit of countering toasty malt sweetness.  Hazy medium amber color, head is slight (which is to be expected).  Flavor profile is massively hoppy, but not overwhelmingly bitter, somehow, spicy and citric, finishing with touches of honeyish malt and pine.  Just a touch of alcohol detected.  Smooth and oily on the palate with a medium-full body.  Quite nice!  Thanks to beastiefan2k for the sample.

Growler courtesy of MatSciGuy - THANKS! Pours copper clear with minimal head. Aroma is all floral hops, with notes of pine, grass, caramel and grapefruit. Flavor is sweet with some bitterness to balance out the flavor. Good stuff!

Growler shared by Taverner, pours deep amber with a finger thick cream colored head that leaves some nice lacing. Floral and grassy nose with decent caramel sweetness. Flavor is grassy and pine with caramel and a dry, spicy finish.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 A growler of this showed up to our recent stout tasting, and what a nice break from all the stouts. Glowing orange pour, good clarity, with a thin white head. Thick resiny personality, sweet candy-like citrus hop flavor, fruity and sticky. Smooth and over-the-top on hop flavor, but actually nicely balanced on the bitterness. Fricken awesome brew.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 ++++ RE-RATE 28 November 2012 ++++Pint can purchased at Zipps in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Canned on 11/14/12 according to stamp on the bottom of the can. The pour is a slight haze orange golden with a well formed one inch light tan head. The head falls slow with thick lacing.  The aroma is fresh resin tropical fruit hops, along with a fruit stripe gum sweetness. The taste has the pineapple fruit up front, along with resin dankness then turns towards more bright sweetness, and a somewhat rough malt character.  The finish is dry leafy grassy hops.  There is also a solid amount of alcohol heat in the back that further dries the finish out. The palate is medium bodied, tiny soft carbonation bubbles, and the dry bitter hop and hot finish. This beer is solidly made, real fresh, and I imagine it is precisely what they intended to brew. However, this is not 100% my thing at the moment.  I used to really enjoy this type of beer. Thanks to Tyler for the fresh can, with an assist to my Dad. Ill keep the original score for posterity sake.  (7,4,7,3,14 - 3.5)

++++ Original Rating - 19 January 2009 ++++ Handbottle shared by beastiefan2k at Indras Strong Ale Fest. Pour is cloudy orange ruby, with a smallish off white head. Nice thick lacing left behind on the glass as the head falls. Aroma is honey sweet, with gritty grainy resinous hops. Taste is the gritty resin citrus pine hops, sweet malty honey, and some nice floral expressions to the back. Palate is medium, pretty sticky and lasting finish. Nice one, thanks Eugene. (8,4,7,3,16 - 3.8)

Thanks for sharing, beastiefan2k. The body was deep orange copper with an off white head. The aroma was woody with some light grapefruit. The taste was light sweet grains and citrus. There was also some bologna and wood. A thick mouth feel. Decent.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Nice DIPA. Hops were still very prominent, even after a few weeks in the growler. Aroma is nice and floral, with hints of copper and orange. Pours a dark amber with a thick head. Flavor is more flowers, with lots of citrus fruit and pine. Lots of orange peel, and touches of grapefruit and maybe even pineapple. Malt keep everything in balance. Notes of oats and tobacco in the background. Finishes like iced tea. Very nice, thanks to tjthresh for sharing.

Growler shared by JCB. Thanks Jason.  Nose is all sorts of fruity hops--tropical, citrus, mango, skunky stick icky--just like i like it. Flavor is nicely bitter with more fruitiness and some nice skunk.  Hope they make this again and put it in a can, although  like ogglethorp says, Id love to try it fresh from the tap.

Growler.   Pours hazy amber color with a decent sized off white head.   Aroma of grapefruit, pine, light caramel, orange.   Flavor is again grapefruit, pine, mango, pear, orange.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished bitter.   This was fantastic, cant imagine how great it would be fresh from the tap.  A+

Special thanks to Beerlando for hooking us all up with a growler.  Aroma is strong and sweet.  Mostly vanilla and citrus hops.  Flavor is lighter, with more bitter hops and vanilla, but also a nice malty finish.  Fairly sweet, as well.  Very well balanced and very good.

Dark hazy copper with a frothy off white head. The aroma has a bit of the onion that you get in Furious. The citrus and pine are well blended. Flavor has plenty of malt and hops, and the balance is pretty amazing. Full body. Sweetish finish.  Thanks to tytoanderso.

Growler. Thanks, Yonkers! Oh, Surly, Surly, Surly, how my heart beats for you after trying this beer. Pours an opaque super-dark amber with a dense gray head. Huge nose of pine, fresh-cut wood, and some big fruity marijuana. Creamy, thick, sticky body. Nutty, toasty, piney, weedy mid-palate. Long dry finish. Cracing, refreshing, loaded with flavor, and still perfectly harmonious throughout. Lots of DIPAs are just pretending. 16 Grit is the real thing.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2009 Growlers courtesy of Buebie and DBhog shared with 50+ of my closest friends at the Brick Store.  Poured into a tulip.

Pours a slightly hazy orangish amber with a small tan head that showed decent retention and spotty lacing.

Upon opening, the growler threw off one of the most appetizing aromas I have ever smelled.  It was just about every fruit you could imagine in an IPA just streaming out.  Grapefruit was the most prominent aroma but there was oranges, lemons, and other tropical fruits.  There was a bit of caramel malt sweetness in the there as well.

The taste follows the aroma and is almost as spectacular.  Its still all about the fruity hops - grapefruit especially.  The caramel malts balance the taste well and there was a subtle bitterness that took a backseat to the fruits.

The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied for the style with good carbonation and less abrasive than most DIPAs.

It is quite possibly the most drinkable DIPA I have tasted and one of the better beers I have tried in a while.  Excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 growler from mr. anderson.... pours a semi-murky dark amber brown with a thin quickly dissipating thin soapy white head....hops and malt work in tandem and combine for a balanced nose of tropical fruit and an equal dose of caramel malts..... flavors swayed toward the sweeter side of things with much attention paid to sweet tropical hops and very little bitterness although some citrus rinds peak through in the finish.  malts are there to support the aforementioned hops.  carbonation level more than adequate and good mouthfeel.  i kind of want to say that this reminds me of pliney the younger.

Growler that Ty was able to pick this up for me, thanks man.  I pop open the growler and the hoppy aroma just wafts the room.  It pours a thick, dark orange color into a white wine glass, can barely see through it.  The large head fades quickly. Aroma is very sweet, definitely underattenuated, with thick topical fruity hops. It is sweet, thick, and hoppy. Taste follows suit with sweet bubblegum hops.  Its a sweet hop brew with sweet underattenuated sugars.  In this case, this worked for me.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Sampled from a growler sent by MatSciGuy - thanks, Levi!!! Ethan thinks hes badass because he called the Amarillo. Whatever, man. But seriously, this is a sick, sick, sick beer. The nose is possibly the most intense Ive encountered for the style, which is saying something. I told myself that I would write a one-word review: DANK. While that captures the beer to some extent, I must rave on. As we head into winter (such as it is in NC), I feel like this beer is springtime personified, with all the rawness, the pungency, the intense freshness. We just smelled it forever, but as floral as the nose is, the taste is amazingly rich, resinous, and bitter. Just what you want from a DIPA. My goodness, Surly, please dont leave this one behind. Outstanding.

Huge thanks to JCB for sharing this. We had some biggies last night (Darkness, Charlevoix Vobiscum, etc..) but this one was easily the highlight of the get together.
Pours a soft peachy amber with a one finger creamy light tan head. The nose is extremely pungent, one of the better aromas Ive ever had the privilege  of experiencing. Very fruity and resinous, lots of citrus, sweet malt background, mango, definitely getting the Amarillo here. The flavor is fruity, mango, nice bitterness, sweet, grapefruit rind, very resinous and fresh, piney. I called the Amarillo in this before I even read it had it. Flavor and aroma wreaks of the citrusy Amarillo. Palate has a very nice full body and a mellow bitterness. Amazing.

Smelled like concentrated hops and tastes like eating a hop pellet.  Some malt sweetness, which makes it surprisingly well balanced for a beer so loaded with hop bitterness. Thanks to Skyview for sharing this one that I missed from Surly.

Thanks to Beerlando for procuring this growler! Hazy reddish amber pour with a thick off white head. Pungent spicy grapefruit hop aroma very aggressive. Taste is big, but not as big as the aroma. Nice malt body and big grapefruit, resiny pine with a caramel malt balance. Finishes big and bitter, grapefruit like. I dig this a lot, my type of DIPA.

Growler, graciously sent down by DalzAle.  The body is lightly hazy, dark reddish-orange in color.  A frothy, bubbly, cream colored head displays nice retention, leaving sticky, jagged lines and crude spots of lacing on the glass.  Aromas of juicy naval oranges, lemon rind, and grapefruit are as fresh as they come.  Resinous pine and sharp, green grass join the hop party, while sweet toffee and honey malts lend balance.  Tropical mango is faintly detectable as well, lending further depth to the delectable nose.  Flavors follow suit, huge citrus hops and toffee malts crashing into one another, intertwining into a rich and robust concoction.  Very lemony, with a big grapefruit and grass presence, the hoppy bitterness is calmed significantly by the equally massive, sweet, honey-glazed caramel-toffee malts.  Thick and nearly full on the palate, the mouthfeel is heavy but never cloying.  This is just a great brew from Surly.  Im sad to see their growler program going by the wayside, at least for the time being.  If only those Minnesota politicians would taste this brew, they would certainly change the law!

Sweet baby Jesus, this is good beer. Beautiful aroma... big, sticky, skunky, resiny, but hugely fruity as well. Tropical fruits and honey. Mango, citrus zest, and even perhaps some tart apple?  Great balance of hops and malt and resin/citrus/fruit.

Growler generously shared by JCB.

growler shared with most the orlando crew thanks to Beerlando!  this was quite a treat to try!  Sweet pine, honey malts with resinous pine notes on the nose.  Pours a rish gold with a thin white head.  Sticky pine resin in the flavor, with a good balance of malts, but still hop forward, an awesome ipa.  Citrus rind, grapefruity as it warms with lemon peel and hints of grassy hops.  A real treat and a pleasure to drink.

Picked up growler at the brewery and shared with the beer gang at Cellars Wine & Spirits. Pours a hazy orange amber brew, some syrup character that brings a thick off-white head that has some nice retention and lots of lacing. As soon as the growler cap was removed I would pick up  grapefruit scent even before pouring into the glass. Aroma of grapefruit, some mango, tropical fruit and a hint of golden grain malt. Taste is full bodied, a little syrupy, with flavors of grapefruit zest, mango, a touch of banana, and a little pine. Finish is semi-sweet, mildly bitter with a lingering grapefruit and pine aftertaste. Well worth the hour wait in line.

Thanks to JCB for sharing!!!  WOW!!!  Dark hazy orange pour with fluffy off white head and spotty lace.   Perfect bittersweet balance.  Lots of tropical fruit.  This is the best  ipa/iipa I’ve had in awhile!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2010 Growler from faro99, huge thanks Jeff. Rating #8. Dark orange pour with a really nice fluffy off-white head. Very nice hop aroma, grapefruity, slight orange even. More grapefruit in the flavor and a nice hop bite in the end, not bitter at all, very well balanced. Tasty shit.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Growler from Tweety.  Huge thanks for this.  Pours a dark, firey, syrupy bright red color with an off-white head.  Hugely aromatic.  Almost dreadnaught like. Very hoppy, mango and orange, tropical fruit and very, very sweet. A little bit of nail polish remover is also noted.  Flavor is cloying, syrupy, sticky sweet.  Bitterness is low.  Good hop flavor though this is just oozing sweetness.  I prefer a much more dry beer for this style.  This had potential but its just too sweet.

Dark amber color, smells great, lots of grapefruit, mango and pine. Very sweet smelling indeed. Taste is a blast of hops followed by a fruity mix that didnt quite overpower the hops. Not near as bitter as Furious, but somewhat balanced. Best smelling IPA I have ever had, and right up there with Hopslam for the top tier of taste.

Poured from a growler. Aroma runs downright musky and rich with sweet perfumed oils, heavy concentrated tangerine and prickly pear juice. Dense. Pours a darker copper and amber, heavily hazed with an off-white rim. Flavor has a very interesting fresh dragonfruit, creamy banana, and heavy wet tropical fruit. Thick and creamy. A peculiar musk rides over this beer in a really nice manner. It balances grasses with heavy tropical fruit. The palate runs a nip sweet. However, there’s a unique, musky tropical grasses, seed, and pit flavor running over this that I assume arises from the high alpha hops. A nice version, kissed with the good edge of Surly house yeast. Nice.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 Growler shared with friends.  Pour was a rich dirty orange color with medium carbonation.  Aroma was very fruity, flavor had lots of orange, grapefruit and of course; HOPS!  For being a stronger beer, it hid the alcohol very well.  I hope Surly reconsiders making this a one time only offering, as Im going to be pretty bummed once I run out of Growlers.

Growler courtesy of BDR and Tdaglow.  Copper color with a medium head.  Strong tangerine and orange aroma.  Some grassy-ness and lemon.  Far stronger caramel malt flavor than I was expecting.  Not overly bitter tasting at all.  Sweet orange peel.  Delicious.  Great way to end 2008!

Growler - also poured courtesy of Omar from the bright tank on the 27th of December and kindly picked up by my wife (I was busy!) A hazy reddish/gold hue, mild carbonation, not too much of a head on it. Sweetness in the nose once you get past the incredible piney and citrus hop aroma. Good caramel malt profile and a balanced, yet bracing bitterness with a mildly sweet finish. You can tell this brew has some punch as it has that nice warm feel to it. I liked it a lot!

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Re-rate on this after I had the can version. The hop profile is quite weak - the beer tastes more like a double malt version of Furious without the super intense mango and citrus character. Taste is really sweet and is like drinking candied apricots. There is a strange plastic character, and lots of oddness going on in the finish. Considering how good Furious is, this one is quite disappointing and dare I say below average.

[Growler] filled directly from the brite tank by Omar. Pours a hazier, slightly darker crimson than the original Furious. The hop profile is extremely similar to that of Furious, lots of mango, grapefruit, pine and citrus, but a touch thicker and there was a lot more malt backbone. Flavor is a lot more malty, and a touch sweeter than its counterpart, but the hops are also significantly more concentrated. This must have been a dangerous beer to brew. If they use too little malt, this monster would have been undrinkable from the crazy amount of bitterness, but it strikes as more balanced, which is honestly a little disappointing.
